questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of chronic heart failure is admitted to the hospital following an episode of acute chest pain. On examination, his heart rate is elevated, and an ECG shows signs consistent with myocardial ischemia. Laboratory findings indicate elevated cardiac enzymes. The patient's condition leads to a discussion among the medical team about the cellular mechanisms of injury in myocardial ischemia. One of the team members mentions that a diminished supply of ATP is a critical factor in the pathophysiology of this condition. Which of the following leads to diminished ATP in the context of cellular injury during myocardial ischemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mitochondrial dysfunction

 

  • Mitochondrial dysfunction leads to diminished ATP production within cells.

  • The mitochondria are the primary site of ATP production through oxidative phosphorylation in aerobic conditions.

  • In the context of myocardial ischemia, as described in the patient's scenario, reduced oxygen supply leads to impaired mitochondrial function.

  • This impairment limits the electron transport chain's ability to produce ATP, directly linking diminished ATP levels to mitochondrial dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intracellular accumulation of Ca2+ does occur in the setting of cellular injury, often as a secondary effect due to the dysfunction of ATP-dependent ion pumps. However, it is not the most direct consequence of diminished ATP related to mitochondrial dysfunction.

 

Option C. Membrane damage is a significant result of cellular injury and can be exacerbated by ATP depletion. However, it typically follows mitochondrial dysfunction and is more of a downstream effect of the initial energy crisis.

 

Option D. The release of lysosomal (hydrolytic) enzymes is a consequence of severe cellular injury and necrosis, which might follow mitochondrial dysfunction and membrane damage but is not the primary consequence of diminished ATP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The educational objective is to recognize the role of mitochondrial dysfunction as a primary and direct consequence of diminished ATP production in the setting of cellular injury, such as in myocardial ischemia.

  • Mitochondria are crucial for ATP synthesis, and their dysfunction underlies many pathophysiological processes associated with ischemic conditions.

 

Summary:

choices.text: Patient must be started on anti-gas gangrene serum therapy
It is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection
Bilateral orchidectomy is generally performed
Compulsory urinary diversion is performed

questions.text: A 67-year-old male patient visits the emergency department due to rapidly worsening pain and swelling in the genital and perianal regions, with signs of necrotizing infection as shown below upon examination. The patient has a history of alcohol abuse and poorly controlled diabetes, and laboratory tests reveal leukocytosis and elevated blood glucose levels. What is the accurate statement about the condition presented by the patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection

 

  • The image provided suggests Fournier's gangrene, which is a mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection and a surgical emergency.
  • Fournier's gangrene is a rapidly progressive infection of the genitalia and perineum caused by mixed bacterial flora, often associated with diabetes, cancer, malnutrition, recent urogenital or colorectal instrumentation, or trauma.
  • Symptoms of Fournier's gangrene include erythema, swelling, pain, and blister formation with ultimately foul-smelling necrotic lesions.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Patient must be started on anti-gas gangrene serum therapy. Incorrect. Anti-gas gangrene serum therapy is typically used for the treatment of gas gangrene caused by the bacterium Clostridium perfringens. While C. perfringens can sometimes be a part of the mixed bacterial flora in Fournier's gangrene, the condition itself is not specifically gas gangrene, and thus anti-gas gangrene serum therapy is not the primary treatment.

 

Option C. Bilateral orchidectomy is generally performed. Incorrect. A bilateral orchidectomy, or the removal of both testes, is not a standard treatment for Fournier's gangrene. Testes are typically spared in Fournier’s gangrene.

 

Option D. Compulsory urinary diversion is performed. Incorrect. While urinary diversion might be considered in some cases where the urethra is compromised or if there's significant involvement of the urogenital structures, it's not a compulsory or routine part of the management of Fournier's gangrene.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Fournier's gangrene, is a mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection and is a surgical emergency.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with a week-long history of fever, abdominal distention, and loss of appetite. His condition has not improved despite treatment with antibiotics and antimalarials. Laboratory tests, including a negative Widal test, have ruled out typhoid fever. However, the RK39 dipstick test, used for the diagnosis of visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar), returns positive. Considering the diagnosis and the need for effective treatment, which of the following drugs is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Liposomal amphotericin B

 

  • Liposomal amphotericin B is the drug of choice for the treatment of visceral leishmaniasis, also known as kala-azar.
  • This formulation of amphotericin B is preferred due to its improved safety profile and efficacy.
  • It targets the fungal cell membrane, causing cell death, and is effective against the protozoa responsible for leishmaniasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bedaquiline is an anti-mycobacterial agent used primarily in the treatment of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis and is not effective against the parasites causing leishmaniasis.

 

Option B. Linezolid is an antibiotic that belongs to the oxazolidinone class and is used to treat infections caused by gram-positive bacteria, including resistant strains like MRSA. It is not used in the treatment of leishmaniasis.

 

Option C. Fluconazole is an antifungal medication used to treat a variety of fungal infections, including candidiasis and cryptococcal meningitis. It is not effective against the protozoan parasites that cause leishmaniasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The question is designed to assess the knowledge of the appropriate pharmacological treatment for visceral leishmaniasis, emphasizing the use of liposomal amphotericin B.
  • It highlights the importance of choosing the correct treatment based on the specific causative agent and the clinical presentation of the disease.

choices.text: Everyone is given the Diphtheria vaccine
Everyone is given Tetanus toxoid
Everyone is given the Cholera vaccine
Only the health workers are given Cholera, Typhoid, and Tetanus toxoid vaccines

questions.text: In the aftermath of a disaster, public health officials must implement a vaccine protocol to prevent the outbreak of diseases among the affected population. Which of the following protocols is typically followed after a disaster situation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Only the health workers are given Cholera, Typhoid, and Tetanus toxoid vaccines

 

  • Following a disaster, the risk of communicable diseases may increase due to a lack of clean water, sanitation, and the disruption of regular health services.
  • Health workers are often at the highest risk as they are directly involved in the care of affected individuals.
  • Consequently, they may be prioritized for vaccination against diseases like Cholera, Typhoid, and Tetanus, which can be more prevalent in such settings.
  • The general population may not be universally vaccinated for these diseases immediately post-disaster unless there is an identified risk or outbreak that necessitates such an intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • WHO does not recommend Typhoid, Cholera and Tetanus Toxoid vaccinations in routine use in endemic areas post-disaster.
  • However, these vaccinations are recommended for health workers

choices.text: Statement A is correct, and Statement B is incorrect.
Statement A is incorrect, and Statement B is correct.
Both Statement A and Statement B are correct.
Both Statement A and Statement B are incorrect.

questions.text:
In the context of cancer metastasis, which of the following statements regarding the role of adhesion molecules is accurate?

 

Statement A: E-cadherin downregulation is often observed in tumor cells, allowing them to detach from primary tumors and invade surrounding tissues.

 

Statement B: Integrins play a crucial role in mediating the attachment of circulating tumor cells to endothelial cells in distant organs, facilitating metastatic spread.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both Statement A and Statement B are correct.

 

Statement A: E-cadherin downregulation is often observed in tumor cells, allowing them to detach from primary tumors and invade surrounding tissues.

 

  • E-cadherin is an adhesion molecule commonly found in epithelial tissues.
  • Its downregulation is associated with Epithelial-Mesenchymal Transition (EMT), a process in which epithelial cells acquire characteristics that enable them to detach from primary tumors and invade surrounding tissues.
  • This is a crucial step in cancer metastasis.

 

Statement B: Integrins play a crucial role in mediating the attachment of circulating tumor cells to endothelial cells in distant organs, facilitating metastatic spread.

 

  • Integrins are a family of cell adhesion receptors that facilitate cell-cell and cell-matrix interactions.
  • In cancer metastasis, integrins on the surface of circulating tumor cells can bind to adhesion molecules on endothelial cells within distant organs, aiding the attachment and extravasation of tumor cells during metastatic spread.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • This question assesses the understanding of the roles of adhesion molecules, specifically E-cadherin and integrins, in cancer metastasis.
  • It highlights the importance of these molecules in tumor invasion and distant organ colonization.

 

Extra-edge:

 

There are four broad families of cell adhesion molecules:

 

  • Integrins: Heterodimers – mediate the interactions between the extracellular matrix and the cytoskeletal framework of the cells.
  • Cadherins: depend on calcium ions – involved in the formation of adherens junctions
  • Ig superfamily: include vascular (VCAM) and neural cell adhesion molecules (NCAM)
  • Selectins: with lectin-like domains binding carbohydrates – involved in inflammation and immune reactions.

 

 

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology, 25th edition, page no. 40

choices.text: Eumycetoma is caused by bacteria.
Surgery is an important component of treatment.
The condition is usually painless.
Diagnosis can be made by examination of the lesion.

questions.text: A 50-year-old farmer from a tropical region presents to the clinic with a chronic, swollen foot with multiple draining sinuses. The sinuses are exuding grains of black material. The patient reports that the foot has been slowly enlarging over several years. The medical team suspects mycetoma based on the clinical presentation. In discussing the case, various statements are made about mycetoma. Which of the following statements is INCORRECT regarding this patient's most likely diagnosis of mycetoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Eumycetoma is caused by bacteria.

 

  • The incorrect statement is that eumycetoma is caused by bacteria.
  • Eumycetoma, also known as "fungal mycetoma," is caused by fungi, not bacteria.
  • The term "mycetoma" refers to a chronic granulomatous infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissues, which can be caused by various species of fungi (eumycetoma) or bacteria (actinomycetoma).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Surgery is an important component of treatment. This is a correct statement. Surgery can be an essential part of treatment for mycetoma, particularly in advanced cases or when there is a need to remove diseased tissue to reduce the load of infection and improve the efficacy of medical therapy.

 

Option C. The condition is usually painless. This is a correct statement. Mycetoma often progresses slowly and is usually painless, which can delay the patient seeking medical attention, leading to more extensive disease.

 

Option D. Diagnosis can be made by examination of the lesion. This is a correct statement. Clinical examination of the characteristic lesions, especially when grains are present in the discharge, is important for diagnosis. Further confirmation can be obtained through histopathological examination and culture of the grains.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Difference between Eumycetoma and Actinomycetoma:

questions.text: A 33-year-old male presents to the clinic with numbness and tingling in the upper cheek, upper lip, and upper gingiva. He reports that the symptoms started a few days after a traumatic injury to the face. Physical examination reveals decreased sensation in the aforementioned areas. The physician suspects an injury to a specific branch of the trigeminal nerve given the distribution of the sensory loss. Which of the following nerves is most likely involved in this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Maxillary nerve (V2)

 

  • The Maxillary nerve (V2) is the second branch of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) and is primarily responsible for providing sensory innervation to the middle third of the face.
  • This includes the upper cheek, upper lip, lower eyelids, and upper gingiva, as well as the maxillary sinuses and the nasopharynx.
  • The symptoms described by the patient, such as numbness and tingling in the upper cheek, upper lip, and upper gingiva, are consistent with an injury to the maxillary nerve, likely as a result of the traumatic facial injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ophthalmic nerve (V1). The ophthalmic nerve provides sensory innervation to the upper third of the face, including the forehead, scalp, and upper eyelid. It does not innervate the areas described by the patient's symptoms.

 

Option C. Mandibular nerve (V3). The mandibular nerve provides motor innervation to the muscles of mastication and sensory innervation to the lower third of the face, including the lower lip, lower gingiva, and chin. The distribution does not match the patient's symptoms.

 

Option D. Facial nerve (VII). The facial nerve primarily provides motor innervation to the muscles of facial expression, taste sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, and some parasympathetic functions. It does not provide general sensory innervation to the face, thus not matching the patient's presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The educational objective of this question is to understand the sensory innervation of the face provided by the branches of the trigeminal nerve, with a focus on the maxillary nerve (V2).
  • Recognizing the distribution of sensory innervation is crucial for localizing nerve injuries based on clinical presentations and for guiding appropriate diagnostic and therapeutic interventions.
  • This knowledge is essential for the differential diagnosis of facial sensory loss and for planning surgical or other interventions in the region of the face.

questions.text: In a clinical immunology seminar focusing on the mechanisms of autoimmune diseases, a group of medical students presents a case study of a 45-year-old woman diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis (RA). They detail her symptoms, including joint pain, stiffness, and swelling, and discuss the laboratory findings, including elevated inflammatory markers and the presence of specific autoantibodies. As part of their presentation, they explore the immune system components implicated in the pathogenesis of RA. Based on current understanding of RA's immunopathology, which of the following immune components is least involved in the initiation and progression of rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neutrophil

 

  • In the context of rheumatoid arthritis, neutrophils are present in the inflamed synovial fluid and contribute to the inflammatory milieu; however, they are not considered central to the disease's initiation and progression.
  • RA is primarily driven by an autoimmune process involving lymphocytes (B cells and T cells), which leads to the production of autoantibodies (such as rheumatoid factor and anti-citrullinated protein antibodies), and macrophages, which secrete pro-inflammatory cytokines.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Macrophage. Macrophages are key players in RA, involved in the secretion of pro-inflammatory cytokines that contribute to joint inflammation and damage.

 

Option C. Lymphocyte. Lymphocytes, including both T cells and B cells, are central to the autoimmune response in RA, with T cells helping to activate B cells, which in turn produce autoantibodies.

 

Option D. Antibody. Autoantibodies, such as rheumatoid factor (RF) and anti-citrullinated protein antibodies (ACPA), are hallmark features of RA and play a significant role in its pathogenesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bottom of FormRheumatoid arthritis (RA):

 

  • Group of auto-antibodies against the host IgG antibodies are produced called RA factor.
  • It is an IgM antibody directed against the Fc region of IgG.
  • Women (40–60 years of age) affected.
  • Autoantibodies bind to circulating IgG, forming IgM-IgG complexes that are deposited in the joints and can activate the complement cascade.
  • Major symptoms:
    • Main feature: Arthritis (chronic inflammation of the joints, begins at synovium; most common joints involved are-small joints of the hands, feet and cervical spine)
    • Other features: Hematologic, cardiovascular, and respiratory systems are also frequently affected

choices.text: Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second (FEV1)
Forced Vital Capacity (FVC)

questions.text: Which of the following parameters cannot be obtained by using the following instrument?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Total capacity

 

  • The instrument shown in the image is a spirometer.
  • It is used to measure various parameters of lung function, most notably those involving the movement of air in and out of the lungs under specific conditions and time constraints.
  • Total lung capacity (TLC) cannot be measured directly by a spirometer because it includes the residual volume (RV), which is the amount of air remaining in the lungs after a full, forceful exhalation and cannot be measured by forced expiration.
  • To measure TLC, additional techniques such as body plethysmography or gas dilution are required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. FEV1. Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second can be measured by a spirometer. It reflects the volume of air that can be forcefully blown out in one second, after full inspiration, and is a critical measure for assessing conditions like asthma and COPD.

 

Option C. FVC. Forced Vital Capacity can be measured by a spirometer and represents the total volume of air that can be forcefully exhaled after full inspiration. It is used to evaluate lung function and to identify obstructive versus restrictive lung disease patterns.

 

Option D. Flow-volume loop. This graphical representation depicts the rate of airflow (on the y-axis) versus the total volume of air exhaled (on the x-axis) during a forceful respiratory maneuver. Spirometers are capable of generating flow-volume loops, which help in the diagnosis and assessment of lung diseases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The spirometry can measure dynamic lung volumes and capacities such as FEV1, FVC, and provide a flow-volume loop, which are essential for the diagnosis and management of respiratory diseases.

choices.text: Increased Phosphate Levels
Raised Calcitonin Levels
Increased Parathyroid Hormone Secretion

questions.text: A 54-year-old female patient presents to her primary care physician for a routine check-up. She has no significant medical history but mentions that she has been following a diet low in calcium for several months due to personal preferences. Concerned about the potential effects of prolonged low calcium intake on her bone health and calcium metabolism, the physician decides to order a series of laboratory tests. Based on the patient's dietary history and the body's physiological response to low calcium levels, which of the following laboratory findings would be most expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased Parathyroid Hormone Secretion

 

  • In response to low dietary calcium intake, the body increases the secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH) to maintain normal serum calcium levels.
  • PTH acts to increased calcium levels by stimulating bone resorption (releasing calcium into the bloodstream), increasing renal reabsorption of calcium, and enhancing the conversion of 25-hydroxyvitamin D to its active form, 1, 25-dihydroxyvitamin D (calcitriol), in the kidneys.
  • Calcitriol then acts to increase dietary calcium absorption from the intestine.
  • Therefore, in the setting of prolonged low calcium intake, one would expect to find increased PTH secretion as the body attempts to compensate for the reduced dietary calcium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased Phosphate Levels. This option is incorrect because increased PTH secretion typically leads to decreased phosphate reabsorption in the kidneys, resulting in lower serum phosphate levels.

 

Option B. Raised Calcitonin Levels. Calcitonin is a hormone that lowers blood calcium levels, but its role in day-to-day calcium homeostasis is less significant than PTH and calcitriol. It is not typically raised in response to low dietary calcium intake.

 

Option D. Activation of 24–25 dihydroxycholecalciferol. This is incorrect because the active form of vitamin D relevant to calcium homeostasis is 1, 25-dihydroxycholecalciferol (calcitriol), not 24–25 dihydroxycholecalciferol. Increased PTH secretion would lead to increased activation of calcitriol.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The educational objective is to understand the body's physiological response to low dietary calcium intake, emphasizing the central role of parathyroid hormone in maintaining calcium homeostasis.
  • Increased PTH secretion in response to low calcium intake highlights the interconnectedness of bone resorption, renal calcium reabsorption, and vitamin D activation in managing serum calcium levels.

choices.text: Fracture of scaphoid has a low incidence of non-union
Scaphoid bone articulates with five bones totally
Scaphoid bone can be easily immobilized
Fracture line on the scaphoid bone may deprive the distal fragment of its arterial supply

questions.text: A  22-year-old male was referred to the emergency room after a fall from height on an outstretched left wrist. Pain and tenderness were noticed in the region of the anatomical snuff box of her left hand. X-ray showed fracture of scaphoid bone. Identify the correct statement.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Scaphoid bone articulates with five bones totally

 

  • Scaphoid bone articulates with Radius (proximally), Trapezium & Trapezoid (distally), Lunate and Head of Capitate (medially).

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Fracture of scaphoid has a low incidence of non-union.

 

  • Scaphoid fractures actually have a relatively high incidence of non-union.

  • This is due to the peculiar blood supply of the scaphoid, where the blood enters the bone distally and travels proximally.

 

 

  • In case of a fracture, especially in the proximal part, this can lead to avascular necrosis and non-union.

  • Common sites of avascular necrosis:

 

 

Option C. Scaphoid bone can be easily immobilized.

 

  • Immobilization of the scaphoid bone can be challenging due to its location and the range of movements in the wrist.

  • Proper healing often requires a specific type of cast or splint known as GLASS HOLDING CAST that immobilizes not just the wrist but also the thumb, as movement of the thumb can disturb the scaphoid.

 

 

Option D. Fracture line on the scaphoid bone may deprive the distal fragment of its arterial supply.

 

  • In scaphoid fractures, it is typically the proximal fragment that is at risk of losing its blood supply, not the distal fragment.

  • This is because the blood supply to the scaphoid enters distally and travels proximally.

  • If there is a fracture,  dividing the bone into proximal and distal fragments, it can compromise the blood flow to the proximal fragment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Scaphoid Bone Articulates with Five Bones Totally: The scaphoid bone, one of the carpal bones in the wrist, articulates with five other bones: the radius proximally; the trapezium distally on the thumb side; and the lunate, capitate, and trapezoid on its ulnar side.

 

Ref: Grays Anatomy, 41st edition, page no. 868

choices.text: Blood clots in the endometrial cavity
Heteroechoic contents seen in the uterine cavity
Normal endometrial lining
The gestational sac seen low down in the uterine cavity

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with a history of two previous live births presents with symptoms suggestive of a complete abortion. She reports having experienced heavy bleeding, cramping, and the passage of tissue. To evaluate her current status and ensure that the abortion was complete, an ultrasound is performed. Which of the following findings would most likely be expected on ultrasound in the case of a complete abortion?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Normal endometrial lining

 

  • In the case of a complete abortion, the expected ultrasound finding would be a normal endometrial lining, indicating that all products of conception have been expelled from the uterus.
  • The absence of any retained tissue or abnormal masses suggests that the abortion process has concluded, and the uterus is returning to its pre-pregnancy state.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blood clots in the endometrial cavity. While blood clots may be present during or immediately after an abortion, their presence on an ultrasound following the resolution of symptoms might suggest retained products of conception rather than a complete abortion.

 

Option B. Heteroechoic contents seen in the uterine cavity. Heteroechoic (mixed echogenicity) contents in the uterine cavity may indicate retained products of conception or other material that has not been expelled, inconsistent with a complete abortion.

 

Option D. The gestational sac seen low down in the uterine cavity. The presence of a gestational sac, especially low in the uterine cavity, might suggest an incomplete abortion or an ongoing pregnancy, rather than a complete abortion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • This question assesses the understanding of ultrasound findings in the context of a complete abortion. Recognizing a normal endometrial lining as an indication of a complete abortion is crucial for the management of patients presenting with symptoms of abortion.
  • Identifying the presence of blood clots, heteroechoic contents, or a gestational sac would suggest incomplete abortion and potentially necessitate further medical intervention.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a 5-year history of Parkinson's disease is seen in the clinic for a follow-up visit. He has been on levodopa/carbidopa therapy but reports increasing periods of immobility. His neurologist is considering adding another medication to help reduce these off periods. Which of the following medications, working by inhibiting the enzyme catechol-O-methyltransferase, would be most appropriate to add to this patient's regimen?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tolcapone

 

  • Tolcapone is a medication used in the management of Parkinson's disease as an adjunct to levodopa/carbidopa therapy.
  • It works by inhibiting the enzyme catechol-O-methyltransferase (COMT), which metabolizes levodopa in the periphery, thereby increasing the availability of levodopa in the brain and prolonging its effects.
  • This can be particularly beneficial in reducing "off" periods in patients with advancing Parkinson's disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amantadine. This drug is an antiviral that also has anti-Parkinsonian properties. It is thought to work by releasing dopamine from existing stores in the nerve terminals and possibly by blocking the reuptake of dopamine into the nerve endings. It does not inhibit catechol-O-methyltransferase.

 

Option B. Rotigotine. Rotigotine is a dopamine agonist that mimics the action of dopamine in the brain. It is used in the treatment of Parkinson's disease and is administered via a transdermal patch. It does not act by inhibiting catechol-O-methyltransferase.

 

Option C. Selegiline. Selegiline is a selective monoamine oxidase B (MAO-B) inhibitor used in the treatment of Parkinson's disease. It helps to increase and extend the effects of levodopa by inhibiting the breakdown of dopamine in the brain. It does not inhibit catechol-O-methyltransferase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The key educational objective is to understand the pharmacological management of Parkinson's disease, particularly the role of tolcapone.
  • Tolcapone is a catechol-O-methyltransferase (COMT) inhibitor used to increase the bioavailability of levodopa in the brain, thereby reducing "off" periods in patients with Parkinson's disease.
  • It is important to differentiate between the mechanisms of action of various drugs used in Parkinson's disease treatment, such as COMT inhibitors (like tolcapone), MAO-B inhibitors (like selegiline), dopamine agonists (like rotigotine), and others (like amantadine).

choices.text: MOOSE – Meta-analysis of Observational Studies
PRISMA – Systematic Review and Meta-analysis

questions.text: In the realm of academic research, specific guidelines are established to standardize the reporting of various types of studies, ensuring clarity, transparency, and reproducibility. Each set of guidelines is tailored to a particular study design, ranging from randomized controlled trials to case reports. Given the following options, identify which pair incorrectly matches a set of guidelines with the corresponding study design.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CARE – Randomized Controlled Trials

 

  • The CARE (Case Reports) guidelines are specifically designed for the reporting of case reports, not Randomized Controlled Trials (RCTs).
  • They aim to standardize the reporting of clinical cases to improve the quality of published case reports and ensure valuable information is not omitted.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CONSORT– Randomized Controlled Trials. Correctly matched, as it provides a checklist and flow diagram for reporting Randomized Controlled Trials.

 

Option B. MOOSE– Meta-analysis of Observational Studies. Appropriately matched with the Meta-analysis of Observational Studies, offering a comprehensive checklist for reporting these types of studies.

 

Option D. PRISMA– Systematic Review and Meta-analysis. Correctly paired with Systematic Review and Meta-analysis, offering guidance for reporting systematic reviews, particularly those that assess the benefits and harms of healthcare interventions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • CONSORT for RCTs, MOOSE for observational study meta-analyses, CARE for case reports, and PRISMA for systematic reviews and meta-analysis.

choices.text: A simple petrol bomb thrown by hand
Named after the Molotov, a foreign minister of Russia, who died after consuming a cocktail

questions.text: A forensic expert is lecturing at a medical college on the types of injuries commonly seen in victims of civil unrest. One topic of discussion is the "Molotov cocktail," a term that appears in both medical and legal investigations involving improvised incendiary devices. Based on the forensic context, how is a "Molotov cocktail" best characterized?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A simple petrol bomb thrown by hand

 

  • In this scenario, the explosive device used is a Molotov cocktail, which is a simple petrol bomb typically thrown by hand.
  • It consists of a glass bottle filled with a flammable liquid, usually petrol/gasoline, and a cloth wick that is lit before throwing.
  • Its use is associated with irregular warfare or civil unrest situations.

 

Note: Incendiary bombs, e.g. napalm bombs primarily cause burns. Usually, phosphorus and magnesium are added. Temperature of 1000C is produced.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A mixed device bomb. Incorrect. A "Molotov cocktail" is not a bomb in the traditional sense but rather an improvised incendiary device.

 

Option C. Named after the Molotov, a foreign minister of Russia, who died after consuming a cocktail. Molotov, foreign minister of Russia, died after having the cocktail: Incorrect. The term "Molotov cocktail" does not refer to an actual cocktail or the manner of death of Molotov, a Soviet politician. The name is derived from Vyacheslav Molotov, a Soviet foreign minister, but it's used symbolically for the device.

 

Option D. A type of tank. Incorrect. A "Molotov cocktail" has no relation to tanks or armored vehicles.

Educational Objective:

 

“Molotov cocktail" is a simple hand-thrown petrol bomb used as an improvised incendiary weapon, distinct from conventional bombs or other military equipment.

choices.text: Duhamel surgery
Kasai procedure
Kimura surgery
Conservative management

questions.text: A 1-month old baby boy presents with progressive, persistent jaundice after birth. The baby is breastfed exclusively and has been feeding well. On examination, there is yellowish discoloration of skin, mildly distended abdomen, and hepatomegaly. Technetium-99m iminodiacetic acid scan shows radionuclide that is concentrated in the liver but not excreted into the intestine. What is the treatment of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kasai procedure

 

  • The condition mentioned above is Biliary atresia.
  • The Japanese and Anglo-Saxon classification describes three main types (Kasai):
    • Type I: atresia restricted to the CBD
    • Type II: atresia of the common hepatic duct
    • Type IIa: a patent gallbladder and a patent CBD are present
    • Type IIb: the gallbladder, cystic duct and CBD are also obliterated
    • Type III: atresia of the right and left hepatic ducts and the entire extrahepatic biliary tree
  • Clinical:
    • About one-third of patients are jaundiced at birth; in all affected babies, jaundice is present by the end of the first week and deepens progressively.
    • The meconium may be a little bile-stained, but later the stools are pale and the urine is dark.
    • Pruritus is severe.
    • Clubbing and skin xanthomas, probably related to raised serum cholesterol, may be present
  • Associations: Polysplenia, situs inversus, absent vena cava and preduodenal portal vein
  • Diagnosis:
    • Fasting USG is the gold standard when biliary atresia is suspected.
    • A shrunken gallbladder, a hyperechogenic liver hilum (‘triangular cord sign‘) or a cyst at the liver hilum without bile duct dilatation with associated anomalies support the diagnosis.
    • Hepatobiliary scintigraphy may reveal the diagnosis but MRCP is highly sensitive and specific in the diagnosis.
    • Inflammatory cells, a fibrotic liver parenchyma exhibiting signs of cholestasis and biliary neoductal structures establishes the definite diagnosis on liver biopsy.
    • Treatment: The Kasai hepatico-portoenterostomy
    • In the majority of cases in which the proximal hepatic ducts are either very small (type II) or atretic (type III) are treated by the Kasai procedure, in which radical excision of all bile duct tissue up to the liver capsule is performed.
    • A Roux-en-Y loop of jejunum is anastomosed to the exposed area of liver capsule above the bifurcation of the portal vein, creating a portoenterostomy.
    • Type I lesions: A direct Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The treatment of choice in Biliary atresia is Kasai procedure.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery, 28th edition, page no. 1240-41

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with a history of smoking is diagnosed with advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). Her tumor testing shows high PD-L1 expression without any EGFR or ALK mutations. You discuss treatment options with her, focusing on targeted immunotherapy that can enhance her immune system's ability to fight cancer. You consider prescribing a PD-L1 inhibitor, which blocks the interaction between PD-1 on T cells and PD-L1 on tumor cells, thereby preventing the inhibition of the immune response against the tumor. All of the following medications are PD-L1 inhibitors used in the treatment of various cancers, including NSCLC, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cetuximab

 

  • Cetuximab is a monoclonal antibody that targets the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) on the surface of cancer cells, not PD-L1.
  • It is used in the treatment of certain types of colorectal cancer and head and neck cancer.
  • Cetuximab works by inhibiting the EGFR pathway, which is involved in cell growth and survival, thereby inhibiting the growth of cancer cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Avelumab is a PD-L1 inhibitor that binds to PD-L1 and blocks its interaction with PD-1, enabling the immune system to recognize and attack tumor cells.

 

Option B. Atezolizumab is another PD-L1 inhibitor used in the treatment of various cancers, including NSCLC, by preventing PD-L1 from binding to PD-1 and B7.1 on the surface of T cells and antigen-presenting cells.

 

Option D. Durvalumab is a PD-L1 inhibitor that works similarly to avelumab and atezolizumab by blocking the interaction of PD-L1 with PD-1, enhancing the immune system's ability to attack tumor cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The question aims to assess the understanding of the mechanism of action of different immunotherapeutic agents used in cancer treatment, particularly PD-L1 inhibitors versus EGFR inhibitors.
  • It highlights the importance of targeted therapy in oncology, based on specific molecular markers, and the need for precision medicine in the management of cancer.

choices.text: Basal Cell Carcinoma is the most common Skin Malignancy
Squamous Cell Carcinoma occurs in Sun Exposed and also over Sun protected sites including Mucosae
Squamous Cell Carcinoma is Most Common in Transplant Recipients
Squamous Cell Carcinoma has Pearly Rolled Edges

questions.text: Identify the FALSE statement among the following options.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Squamous Cell Carcinoma has Pearly Rolled Edges

 

  • The description of "pearly rolled edges" typically refers to Basal Cell Carcinoma, not Squamous Cell Carcinoma.
  • SCC often presents as a scaly or crusted lesion with a potential for ulceration, rather than with the pearly appearance associated with BCC.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Basal Cell Carcinoma is the most common skin malignancy. Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC) is indeed the most common form of skin cancer.

 

Option B. Squamous Cell Carcinoma occurs in sun exposed and also over sun protected sites including mucosae. Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC) can occur on sun-exposed skin, such as the head, neck, and arms, as well as in sun-protected areas and mucosal surfaces.

 

Option C. Squamous Cell Carcinoma is Most common in Transplant recipients. SCC is more common in transplant recipients due to immunosuppression, which increases the risk of various skin cancers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The edges of a lesion can provide critical diagnostic clues; in the case of Basal Cell Carcinoma, "pearly rolled edges" are characteristic, whereas Squamous Cell Carcinoma typically does not present with such a feature.

 

Ref: Rooks’ Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page No. 141.8, 142.25

questions.text: In a 57-year-old patient with chronic acid reflux and peptic ulcer symptoms, which type of gastric mucosal cells is primarily responsible for secreting a substance that stimulates the production of hydrochloric acid in the stomach, potentially contributing to the patient's digestive issues?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) G Cells

 

  • G cells, located in the stomach lining, secrete gastrin, which stimulates the production of hydrochloric acid by parietal cells.
  • Different cells secreting hormones are:

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. S cells, located in the intestine, secrete secretin, which regulates water homeostasis in the body, not hydrochloric acid secretion.

 

Option B. H cells are not a recognized cell type involved in the regulation of gastric secretions.

 

Option C. Peptic cells, or chief cells, are primarily responsible for secreting pepsinogen, an enzyme precursor, not a stimulant for hydrochloric acid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understand that G cells in the stomach lining secrete gastrin, a hormone that stimulates the production of hydrochloric acid, playing a crucial role in digestive processes and contributing to conditions like acid reflux and peptic ulcers.

 

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology, 25th edition, page no. 468, 471

choices.text: Leakage of fluid into the peritoneal cavity leading to peritonitis
Fluid wetting the surgeon
Fluids running out during the procedure
Electrolyte imbalance in the patient

questions.text: During a hysteroscopy, a surgeon is performing a diagnostic evaluation on a 35-year-old woman for abnormal uterine bleeding. The procedure involves the introduction of fluid into the uterine cavity to expand it and improve visibility. The surgeon is mindful of the volume and type of fluid used, as well as the patient's fluid balance. Understanding the significance of fluid management during this procedure, which of the following is the most critical reason for careful fluid monitoring during hysteroscopy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Electrolyte imbalance in the patient

 

  • The most critical reason for careful fluid management during hysteroscopy is to prevent electrolyte imbalance in the patient.
  • During hysteroscopy, fluid is used to distend the uterine cavity, which can sometimes be absorbed into the patient's bloodstream.
  • This can lead to a condition known as fluid overload or, depending on the type of fluid used, specific imbalances like hyponatremia if hypotonic solutions are absorbed in significant quantities.
  • Managing the volume and type of fluid used is crucial to prevent these potentially serious complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Leakage of fluid into the peritoneal cavity leading to peritonitis. While fluid can inadvertently enter the peritoneal cavity during procedures, it typically does not lead to peritonitis unless the fluid is contaminated, which is a rare occurrence with proper sterile techniques.

 

Option B. Fluid from wetting the surgeon. While maintaining a dry surgical field is important for the comfort of the surgical team and the integrity of the procedure, it is not the most critical reason for fluid management during hysteroscopy.

 

Option C. Fluids running out during the procedure. Preventing fluid loss is important for maintaining visibility and distension of the uterine cavity during hysteroscopy, but it is not as critical as preventing electrolyte imbalances in the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The primary objective of careful fluid management during hysteroscopy is to prevent electrolyte imbalances in the patient, such as hyponatremia, which can occur due to the absorption of irrigation fluids into the bloodstream.
  • Understanding the implications of fluid absorption and the potential for fluid overload is essential for the safe conduct of hysteroscopic procedures.

questions.text: Identify the abnormality.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Morning glory syndrome

 

  • The given image shows:
    • A large disc with a funnel-shaped excavation surrounded by a ring-shaped chorioretinal disturbance.
    • Blood vessels emerge from the rim of excavation radially, like spokes of a wheel.
    • Veins and arteries are difficult to distinguish.
    • Persistent hyaloid vascular remnants are seen as a white tuft of glial tissue overlying the centre.
  • All these features make the optic disc look like a morning glory flower, hence the name.

 

 

  • Morning glory anomaly may be unilateral and sporadic condition or bilateral and hereditary (rarer).
  • PAX6 gene mutation may be present.
  • The most important systemic association is frontonasal dysplasia.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Optic Disc Pit. An optic disc pit is a congenital anomaly characterized by a small, round or oval, greyish depression in the optic nerve head, often associated with potential complications like serous macular detachment.

 

 

Option B. Posterior staphyloma. Posterior staphyloma is a localized protrusion or bulging of the sclera (the white outer layer of the eye) at the back of the eye, often associated with severe myopia (near-sightedness) and thinning of the scleral tissue.

 

 

Option D. Advanced glaucomatous cupping. Advanced glaucomatous cupping refers to the deepening and enlargement of the optic cup in the optic nerve head, a sign of progressive damage caused by glaucoma, leading to a distinctive cup-to-disc ratio increase and corresponding vision loss.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Morning Glory Syndrome is a congenital, enlarged, funnel-shaped optic disc anomaly.

choices.text: Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with complaints of bone pain and muscle weakness that have progressively worsened over the past year. She also reports frequent urination and a recent history of kidney stones. Physical examination reveals diffuse bone tenderness and decreased muscle tone. Laboratory tests show low serum calcium, high serum phosphate, and elevated alkaline phosphatase levels. Urinalysis reveals increased phosphate excretion. A bone density scan indicates decreased bone density consistent with osteomalacia. Based on the patient's clinical presentation and laboratory findings, which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fibrosarcoma

 

  • The patient's presentation of bone pain, muscle weakness, phosphaturia, osteomalacia, and the laboratory findings of low serum calcium, high serum phosphate, and elevated alkaline phosphatase are indicative of oncogenic osteomalacia, also known as tumor-induced osteomalacia (TIO).
  • TIO is most commonly associated with mesenchymal tumors such as fibrosarcoma.
  • These tumors produce fibroblast growth factor 23 (FGF23), which leads to phosphaturia and subsequent osteomalacia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Osteosarcoma. This is a type of bone cancer that typically presents with localized bone pain and swelling. It is not typically associated with metabolic conditions like phosphaturia and osteomalacia.

 

Option C. Undifferentiated sarcoma. This term refers to a group of sarcomas that cannot be more specifically categorized. While they can cause local bone destruction, they are not typically associated with systemic metabolic effects like phosphaturia and osteomalacia.

 

Option D. Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor. These are rare soft tissue sarcomas that arise from the peripheral nerves. They typically present with a palpable mass and pain or neurological deficits, not with systemic metabolic disturbances like phosphaturia and osteomalacia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The educational objective is to recognize the clinical and laboratory findings associated with oncogenic osteomalacia (tumor-induced osteomalacia), including phosphaturia, osteomalacia, low serum calcium, high serum phosphate, and elevated alkaline phosphatase levels, and to understand its association with mesenchymal tumors such as fibrosarcoma that produce fibroblast growth factor 23 (FGF23).

choices.text: Estimation of time since death
Deciding the cause of death
Determining the manner of death
Assessing the liquification of tissues

questions.text: In a District hospital, a casualty medical officer was faced with a peculiar case. A group of hikers had discovered a body in a densely wooded area on the outskirts of the city. The body was in an advanced state of decomposition. Given the outdoor setting and variable environmental conditions, the medical officer decided to utilize Casper's dictum to potentially assist in the ongoing police investigation. In this context, what is the primary application of Casper's dictum by the medical officer?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Estimation of time since death

 

  • Casper's dictum is a principle used in forensic medicine that provides a comparative rate of decomposition under different conditions, aiding in the estimation of the post-mortem interval or time since death.
  • It is based on the observation that a body decomposes twice as fast in air than in water and eight times as fast as in earth, given similar conditions.
  • This guideline is particularly useful in outdoor scenarios, where environmental factors play a significant role in the rate of decomposition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Deciding the cause of death. This involves a thorough investigation including autopsy, toxicology, and histology, which is not directly related to Casper's dictum.

 

Option C. Determining the manner of death. This categorizes the death as natural, accidental, suicidal, or homicidal, which is beyond the scope of Casper's dictum.

 

Option D. Assessing the liquification of tissues. While Casper's dictum involves understanding the decomposition process, its primary use is not to assess tissue liquification but rather to estimate the time since death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Casper's dictum is a rule used to estimate the time since death by comparing the rates of decomposition in air, water, and soil.
  • The rate of putrefaction is faster in air (e.g.- 8 hrs) followed by water (e.g.- 2 hrs) and least in soil or earth (e.g.- 1 hr).

choices.text: Stapled hemorroidopexy
Well's procedure
Thiersch stitch
Altemeier repair

questions.text: A 60-year-old male underwent surgery for rectal prolapse, and a postoperative image was obtained. Can you identify the procedure that was most likely performed on the patient from the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thiersch stitch

 

  • The postoperative image suggests the use of Thiersch wiring for rectal prolapse.
  • Thiersch's wiring involves placing a steel wire or a silastic/nylon tape around the anal canal.
  • It is now rarely done due to post-operative problems such as chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis, and obstructed defecation.

 

Other options: 

 

Option A. Stapled hemorrhoidopexy. A minimally invasive surgical technique used to treat internal hemorrhoids by repositioning prolapsed tissue back to its normal anatomical position with a circular stapling device.

 

Option B. Well's procedure. An abdominal procedure for rectal prolapse that involves repositioning and attaching the rectum to the sacrum using sutures, often reinforced with mesh.

 

Option D. Altemeier repair. A perineal approach to resect and anastomose the prolapsed rectum.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Thiersch's wiring involves placing a steel wire or a silastic/nylon tape around the anal canal for rectal prolapse.

choices.text: The active site is the same as the allosteric site in enzymes.
All allosteric enzymes exhibit positive cooperativity.
An allosteric inhibitor is not a structural analogue of the substrate.
The activity of allosteric enzymes is described by the Michaelis-Menten equation.

questions.text: During a biochemistry lecture on enzyme regulation, a medical instructor discusses the unique properties of allosteric enzymes and their significance in metabolic pathways. One student asks about the distinction between the active and allosteric sites of these enzymes and their implications for enzyme kinetics and regulation. The instructor decides to use this opportunity to test the students' understanding by asking which of the following statements about allosteric enzymes is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) An allosteric inhibitor is not a structural analogue of the substrate.

 

  • Allosteric inhibitors bind to sites on an enzyme that are distinct from the active site, known as allosteric sites.
  • The binding of an allosteric inhibitor to an enzyme induces a conformational change that reduces the enzyme's activity but does not involve structural mimicry of the enzyme's substrate.
  • This distinguishes allosteric regulation from competitive inhibition, where the inhibitor is often a structural analogue of the substrate and competes for binding at the active site.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The active site is the same as the allosteric site in enzymes. This statement is incorrect because the active site is where substrate binding and catalysis occur, whereas the allosteric site is a separate site where regulatory molecules bind, influencing the enzyme's activity through conformational changes.

 

Option B. All allosteric enzymes exhibit positive cooperativity. Not all allosteric enzymes display positive cooperativity. Allosteric enzymes can show either positive or negative cooperativity, or none at all, depending on how the binding of a ligand at one site affects the binding of additional ligands at other sites.

 

Option D) The activity of allosteric enzymes is described by the Michaelis-Menten equation. Allosteric enzymes do not typically follow Michaelis-Menten kinetics because their activity is not described by a simple hyperbolic relationship between enzyme activity and substrate concentration. Instead, their kinetics often exhibit a sigmoidal (S-shaped) curve due to cooperative binding effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • This question aims to clarify the concepts related to allosteric enzymes, focusing on the distinction between active and allosteric sites, the nature of allosteric regulation, and the kinetic properties of these enzymes.
  • Understanding these principles is crucial for comprehending the regulation of metabolic pathways and the mechanisms of action of certain pharmaceuticals that target allosteric sites.

choices.text: Pack the cervix and remove the pack after 4-6 hours
Suture the cervical tear vaginally
Laparotomy and suture the cervical tear from above

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman delivers a 3.4 kg baby at 38 weeks’ gestation using outlet forceps due to a prolonged second stage of labor. Following the successful delivery of the baby and the complete delivery of the placenta, she experiences profuse bleeding. The uterus is found to be well-contracted upon examination. Further examination of the vagina and cervix reveals a cervical tear. Given this scenario, what would be the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Suture the cervical tear vaginally

 

  • In the case of a cervical tear following delivery, the most appropriate management is direct suturing of the tear vaginally, especially if the tear is accessible and the bleeding is significant.
  • This approach allows for immediate control of the hemorrhage and repair of the injury.
  • Cervical tears can be a source of significant postpartum hemorrhage, and timely intervention is crucial to prevent excessive blood loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pack the cervix and remove the pack after 4-6 hours. Cervical packing is a more conservative approach and might be considered in cases where bleeding is minimal or when immediate surgical intervention is not possible. However, it does not directly address the repair of the tear and can be associated with infection or continued bleeding.

 

Option C. Laparotomy and suture the cervical tear from above. Laparotomy for suturing a cervical tear is highly invasive and generally not indicated unless there are additional intra-abdominal injuries or complications that cannot be managed vaginally.

 

Option D. Administer anti-fibrinolytics. While anti-fibrinolytics like tranexamic acid can be useful in managing postpartum hemorrhage, they do not directly address the mechanical cause of bleeding, such as a cervical tear. This option might be used adjunctively but not as the primary intervention for a cervical tear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • This question highlights the importance of promptly identifying and managing cervical tears following delivery, especially when they are the source of significant postpartum hemorrhage.
  • Direct suturing of the tear via a vaginal approach is often the most appropriate and effective intervention.
  • Other management strategies, such as cervical packing or the use of anti-fibrinolytics, may have a role in specific contexts but are not the primary treatment for a cervical tear.
  • Laparotomy is generally reserved for more complex cases where vaginal access is not sufficient or other intra-abdominal injuries are suspected.

choices.text: Derivative of First Pharyngeal Pouch
Develops from Second Pharyngeal Pouch
Develops from Third Pharyngeal Pouch
Derivative of Fourth Pharyngeal Pouch

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents to the clinic with a sore throat, fever, and difficulty swallowing for the past two days. On examination, the child appears irritable, with enlarged and erythematous tonsils, each displaying a white exudate. No rash is observed. The child's mother reports that the child has had similar episodes in the past. Considering the anatomical origin of the affected structure, where do the tonsils develop from?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Develops from Second Pharyngeal Pouch

 

  • The clinical scenario describes a typical case of acute tonsillitis, commonly seen in pediatric patients.
  • The tonsils, which are lymphoid tissues, play a role in the immune response to oral pathogens.
  • Embryologically, the palatine tonsils, which are most commonly involved in tonsillitis, develop from the second pharyngeal pouch.
  • Epithelial lining of tonsil and tonsillar crypts is formed from the endoderm of the ventral part of the second pharyngeal pouch.

 

 

  • Lymphatic follicles of tonsil are derived from mesoderm.
  • Neural crest cells also migrate into developing pharyngeal arches.
  • Intratonsillar cleft/Crypta magna represents non-obliterated part of second pharyngeal pouch.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Derivative of First Pharyngeal Pouch. The first pharyngeal pouch gives rise to structures like the middle ear cavity, Eustachian tube, and the inner layer of the tympanic membrane, not the tonsils. Therefore, this option is incorrect for the origin of the tonsils.

 

Option C. Develops from Third Pharyngeal Pouch. The third pharyngeal pouch is responsible for the development of the inferior parathyroid glands and the thymus. It does not contribute to the formation of the tonsils.

 

Option D. Derivative of Fourth Pharyngeal Pouch. The fourth pharyngeal pouch primarily contributes to the formation of the superior parathyroid glands and, in part, the ultimobranchial body which contributes to the thyroid gland. It does not give rise to the tonsils.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The palatine tonsils, develop from the second pharyngeal pouch.
  • The epithelial lining of this pouch proliferates and invaginates, forming the crypts of the tonsils.
  • Lymphoid tissue then infiltrates these crypts during later development.Top of Form

 

Ref: Textbook of Human Embryology, First Edition, Yogesh Sontakke, Page no. 104

choices.text: Anterior tibio-talar part
Posterior tibio-talar part

questions.text: A 26-year-old professional soccer player presents to the clinic with acute ankle pain following a severe inversion injury during a match. Physical examination reveals significant tenderness and swelling over the medial aspect of the ankle. Radiographic imaging is negative for fractures but suggests a ligamentous injury. The physician suspects injury to a specific component of the medial (deltoid) ligament complex, which is crucial for resisting valgus stress and providing stability to the medial side of the ankle. Which part of the deltoid ligament is most likely involved in this patient's injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tibio-calcaneal part

 

  • The tibio-calcaneal part of the deltoid ligament is a significant component of the medial ligamentous support of the ankle.
  • It extends from the medial malleolus of the tibia to the sustentaculum tali of the calcaneus.
  • This part of the deltoid ligament is crucial for providing stability against valgus forces and preventing excessive eversion of the foot.
  • In the case of a severe inversion injury, as described for the soccer player, the medial ligament complex, particularly the tibio-calcaneal part, is prone to injury due to the forceful overstretching and potential tearing of the ligament fibers.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Tibio-navicular part. This component of the deltoid ligament extends from the medial malleolus to the navicular bone. It plays a role in stabilizing the medial side of the ankle but is less likely to be isolatedly involved in an inversion injury, which typically affects the ligaments on the lateral side of the ankle or the deeper components of the medial side.

 

Option C) Anterior tibio-talar part. This part of the deltoid ligament stretches from the medial malleolus to the talus. It is involved in resisting anterior translation of the talus and internal rotation but is less likely to be the primary site of injury in an inversion sprain.

 

Option D) Posterior tibio-talar part. Extending from the medial malleolus to the talus, this part of the deltoid ligament helps stabilize the ankle against posterior translation of the talus. While it contributes to the overall stability of the ankle, it is less commonly injured compared to the tibio-calcaneal part in inversion injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • This question aims to assess the learner's understanding of the anatomy and function of the deltoid ligament, particularly the tibio-calcaneal part, in providing medial ankle stability.
  • Recognizing the specific components of the deltoid ligament and their roles in ankle stability is crucial for diagnosing ligamentous injuries and guiding appropriate treatment, especially in athletes who sustain inversion injuries of the ankle.
  • Understanding the mechanism of injury and the anatomical structures involved is essential for accurate diagnosis, management, and prevention of further injury in clinical practice.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a history of recurrent, debilitating headaches characterized by unilateral throbbing pain, nausea, and photophobia. These episodes occur approximately 4 times per month and significantly impair her ability to work. After a thorough evaluation, you diagnose her with migraine without aura and discuss treatment options. Given the frequency and severity of her migraines, you consider starting prophylactic therapy to reduce the frequency, severity, and duration of her migraine episodes. Which of the following medications is NOT typically used for the prophylaxis of migraines?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sumatriptan

 

  • Sumatriptan is a serotonin receptor agonist (specifically, a 5-HT1 agonist) that is used for the acute treatment of migraine attacks but is not used for migraine prophylaxis.
  • It works by constricting blood vessels in the brain and blocking pain pathways in the brain, which helps to relieve the symptoms of a migraine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Valproate, an anticonvulsant medication, is effective in reducing the frequency and intensity of migraines and is used for migraine prophylaxis.

 

Option C. Propranolol, a beta-blocker, is commonly used for migraine prophylaxis. It is thought to work by blocking beta-adrenergic receptors, which may be involved in the generation of migraines.

 

Option D. Topiramate, another anticonvulsant, is also used for the prophylactic treatment of migraines. Its mechanism in migraine prevention is not entirely understood but is thought to involve the modulation of neurotransmitter pathways that are implicated in migraine pathogenesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The question aims to assess the understanding of migraine prophylaxis and the differentiation between prophylactic and acute treatment options for migraine.
  • It highlights the importance of choosing the appropriate medication based on the treatment goal, whether it is to prevent future migraine episodes or to treat acute migraine symptoms.

choices.text: Acute Otitis Media with perforation

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a chronic foul-smelling discharge from his right ear, hearing loss, and occasional dizziness. On examination, there is a white mass visible behind the tympanic membrane, and the membrane appears retracted in attic with a pocket formation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cholesteatoma

 

  • A cholesteatoma is an abnormal growth of keratinizing squamous epithelium in the middle ear and mastoid process.
  • It presents with chronic foul-smelling discharge, hearing loss, and can cause dizziness if it affects the inner ear structures.
  • The presence of a white mass in an attic retraction pocket is highly suggestive of cholesteatoma.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Otitis externa, or "swimmer's ear," typically presents with pain, especially with manipulation of the pinna or tragus, and can have discharge, but it does not usually present with a visible mass behind the tympanic membrane or cause chronic symptoms.

 

Option B. Acute otitis media with perforation can lead to discharge and hearing loss, but it is unlikely to present with a white mass behind the tympanic membrane. Perforation usually results in a visible defect in the tympanic membrane.

 

Option D. A vestibular schwannoma, also known as an acoustic neuroma, is a benign tumor of the vestibulocochlear nerve. It typically presents with unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and balance disturbances. It would not be visible behind the tympanic membrane nor present with ear discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The educational objective of this question is to recognize the clinical presentation of a cholesteatoma, which typically includes chronic foul-smelling ear discharge, hearing loss, and the presence of a white mass behind an intact tympanic membrane.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a history of recurrent genital infections. She reports having multiple sexual partners over the past year and admits to inconsistent use of condoms and other protective measures. Her medical history is significant for similar episodes in the past, which temporarily resolved with treatment but recurred upon re-exposure. Given the pattern of transient colonization and the patient's sexual history, which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for her recurrent genital infections?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Neisseria gonorrhoeae

 

  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae, the causative agent of gonorrhea, is a common sexually transmitted infection that can lead to recurrent genital infections, especially in individuals with multiple sexual partners and inconsistent use of protection.
  • Gonorrhea can be effectively treated with antibiotics, but reinfection can occur with subsequent exposures, leading to a pattern of transient colonization and recurrent infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV). HSV causes genital herpes, which is characterized by recurrent painful lesions. Unlike transient colonization, HSV establishes lifelong latency in the host's nerve cells and can reactivate periodically.

 

Option B. Trichomonas vaginalis. This protozoan parasite causes trichomoniasis, a sexually transmitted infection. While it can be recurrent, it is due to reinfection rather than transient colonization.

 

Option C. Haemophilus influenza. This bacterium is primarily associated with respiratory infections and is not commonly linked to recurrent genital infections or sexual transmission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae is known for causing transient colonization, particularly in the genital tract.
  • It is a common sexually transmitted bacterium that can lead to infections like gonorrhea.

questions.text:
During a rural health camp, a medical officer is educating the community about the risks associated with snakebites, particularly from venomous species. The officer emphasizes the importance of recognizing features of poisonous snakes for early identification and management. Which of the following characteristics is NOT typically associated with venomous snakes?

 

  1. They are primarily nocturnal in habit.
  2. They have a compressed tail.
  3. They possess solid and stout fangs.
  4. They exhibit large scales on their head.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3, 4

 

  • Poisonous snakes, particularly those belonging to the viper and elapid families, typically have hollow fangs that act as channels for injecting venom, contradicting statement 3, which suggests solid fangs.
  • Additionally, many venomous snakes have smaller, more numerous head scales rather than large ones, making statement 4 incorrect.

 

 

Other Options:

 

  1. Nocturnal in habit: This is a common characteristic of many poisonous snakes, allowing them to hunt and avoid predators under the cover of darkness.
  2. Have compressed tail: While some venomous snakes may exhibit a compressed tail, this feature is not a definitive indicator of venomous species and varies among different snake families.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Poisonous Vs non-poisonous snakes:

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea has the following features. What is the most probable diagnosis?

 

  • Normal stature
  • Thelarche – absent
  • FSH, LH – high
  • Karyotype – 46 XX
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gonadal dysgenesis

 

  • The probable diagnosis, in this case, is pure gonadal dysgenesis.
  • Whenever secondary sexual characters are ABSENT, think of ovarian or hypothalamic/pituitary causes.
  • If FSH/ LH is low, think of hypothalamic or pituitary causes (Hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism)
  • If FSH/ LH is high, think of ovarian cause (hypergonadotropic hypogonadism)
    • 46 XX – gonadal dysgenesis
    • 46 XY – Swyer syndrome

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Testicular Feminization Syndrome/Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome. 

 

  •  
  • 46 XY
  • Uterus and ovaries absent
  • Secondary sexual development (especially breast development +) due to peripheral production of estrogens.

 

Option C. Kallman Syndrome.

 

  •  
  • This is a cause of Hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism leading to primary amenorrhoea
  • Associated with anosmia
  • Absent secondary sexual characters
  • FSH and LH Low

 

Option D. Turner Syndrome.

 

  •  
  • 45 XO
  • Streak ovaries leading to low estrogen and absent secondary sexual characters
  • FSH and LH are high
  • Very important feature: Short stature

 

Ref: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition, Page no. 454

questions.text:
A healthcare facility is training its staff on the Biomedical Waste Management (BMW) Guidelines for the proper segregation of waste products. The staff is presented with a list of items and a set of coloured dustbins where each colour is designated for a specific type of waste. Match the following items with the correct coloured dustbins according to the BMW Guidelines.

 

 

Using the information provided, select the appropriate colour for each item from the list.
questions.solution: Ans. C) a-4, b-3, c-2, d-1

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe chest pain, dysphagia, and subcutaneous emphysema after a forceful episode of vomiting. The clinical suspicion is high for esophageal perforation. To confirm the diagnosis, an imaging study using a contrast agent is planned. Which of the following contrast agents is most appropriate for diagnosing esophageal perforation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gastrograffin

 

  • Gastrograffin (water-soluble contrast medium) is the preferred initial contrast agent for suspected esophageal perforation due to its lower risk of causing a severe inflammatory response if it leaks into the mediastinum or pleural space compared to barium.
  • While Gastrograffin can still cause an inflammatory response, it is less severe than that caused by barium sulfate.
  • If Gastrograffin does not show clear evidence of perforation and clinical suspicion remains high, a follow-up study with barium might be considered, as barium provides better anatomic detail.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bromium. Bromium is not used as a contrast agent

 

Option C. Gadolinium. Gadolinium is a contrast agent used in magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and is not appropriate for imaging the esophagus in the context of suspected perforation due to its use in a different imaging modality and potential for severe side effects if used outside the vascular system.

 

Option D. Barium sulfate. Barium sulfate provides excellent anatomic detail and is the contrast agent of choice for many gastrointestinal studies. However, in the case of esophageal perforation, barium can cause a severe chemical mediastinitis if it leaks into the mediastinum, making it a less preferred option for initial evaluation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The question aims to test the knowledge of the appropriate use of contrast agents in the diagnosis of gastrointestinal perforations, particularly esophageal perforations.
  • It emphasizes the importance of choosing a contrast agent that minimizes patient risk while providing sufficient diagnostic information.
  • Understanding the properties and appropriate clinical use of various contrast agents, such as Gastrograffin, gadolinium, and barium sulfate, is crucial for safe and effective patient care in radiologic evaluations.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with a history of diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency department with acute onset of high fever, chills, and painful urination. The patient also complains of flank pain and nausea. Urinalysis reveals significant leukocyturia and glycosuria. Given the patient's diabetic status and the acute presentation, a CT scan of the abdomen is performed to further evaluate the cause of these symptoms. Based on the clinical presentation and the patient's background, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Emphysematous pyelonephritis

 

  • Emphysematous pyelonephritis is a severe, necrotizing infection of the renal parenchyma and surrounding tissues that typically occurs in patients with diabetes mellitus.
  • It is characterized by the production of gas within the renal parenchyma, calices, and perinephric tissues, often identifiable on imaging studies such as CT scans.
  • The presence of gas makes this condition distinct from other forms of kidney infections.
  • The acute onset of fever, dysuria, and the patient's diabetic status significantly increase the likelihood of this diagnosis, particularly if the CT scan shows gas formation within or around the kidneys.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute pyelonephritis. This is a bacterial infection that causes the kidneys to swell. While it presents with symptoms similar to those described, the absence of gas formation on the CT scan would make emphysematous pyelonephritis a more likely diagnosis in a diabetic patient.

 

Option C. Perinephric abscess. This is a collection of pus around the kidney, often secondary to pyelonephritis. Although it can occur in diabetic patients, the presence of gas on a CT scan is more indicative of emphysematous pyelonephritis.

 

Option D. Renal abscess. A renal abscess is a localized collection of pus within the renal parenchyma. It might present similarly to the other options but lacks the characteristic gas formation seen in emphysematous pyelonephritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The question is designed to test the ability to recognize and differentiate between severe urinary tract infections in diabetic patients, particularly focusing on emphysematous pyelonephritis.
  • It underscores the importance of considering this life-threatening condition when a diabetic patient presents with symptoms of a UTI and emphasizes the role of imaging, such as a CT scan, in diagnosing emphysematous pyelonephritis by identifying gas within the renal tissues.
  • Understanding the distinctions between acute pyelonephritis, perinephric abscess, and renal abscess is essential for accurate diagnosis and effective management.

choices.text: Position of the cervix
Station of the fetal head
Position of the fetal head

questions.text: The Modified Bishop score is a pre-labor scoring system used to predict the likelihood of successful labor induction and assess the cervix's readiness for labor. It takes into account various cervical and fetal factors. Which of the following is NOT a component of the Modified Bishop score?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Position of the fetal head

 

  • The position of the fetal head is not a component of the Modified Bishop score.
  • The Bishop score assesses cervical readiness for labor by evaluating factors such as cervical dilation, effacement, consistency, and position, as well as the station of the fetal head in relation to the ischial spines.
  • The position of the fetal head (e.g., whether the fetus is facing anterior, posterior, or transverse) does not contribute to this scoring system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Position of the cervix. This refers to whether the cervix is positioned anteriorly or posteriorly in the vagina, which can indicate how advanced labor is. A more anterior position is favourable for labor induction.

 

Option B. Cervical consistency. This assesses whether the cervix feels soft, medium, or firm. A softer cervix is more favourable for labor induction.

 

Option C. Station of the fetal head. This indicates the level of the fetal head in relation to the ischial spines of the pelvis, measured in centimetres. The higher the station, the less engaged the fetal head is, and a lower station indicates that the fetal head is more engaged in the pelvis, which is favourable for labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • This question aims to clarify the components of the Modified Bishop score, which is used to evaluate cervical readiness for labor and the likelihood of successful labor induction.
  • Understanding the components of this score is essential for obstetric management, particularly when deciding on the timing and method of labor induction.
  • The position of the fetal head, while important for other aspects of labor management, is not included in this scoring system.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, who previously underwent an uncomplicated lower segment cesarean section, is currently in labor and has been deemed a candidate for a trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC). The medical team is closely monitoring for any signs of complications, particularly uterine scar rupture, due to her history of cesarean delivery. In this scenario, which of the following is considered the earliest warning sign of uterine scar rupture?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fetal distress
