Option D. Autophagy is a regulated process that involves the degradation and recycling of cellular components in response to stress or nutrient deprivation, which is not directly implicated in the patient's condition related to iron overload.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • This question aims to assess the understanding of ferroptosis, a form of regulated cell death characterized by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation.
  • It highlights the importance of recognizing the role of iron metabolism in various pathophysiological conditions and distinguishing ferroptosis from other forms of cell death such as apoptosis, necrosis, and autophagy.
  • Understanding these processes is crucial in the diagnosis and management of conditions associated with abnormal iron metabolism.

choices.text: William’s syndrome
DiGeorge syndrome
Prader-Willi syndrome
Angelman syndrome

questions.text: A child with coarse facial features, hypercalcemia, and a heart murmur indicative of supravalvular aortic stenosis most likely has which of the following syndromes?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) William’s syndrome

 

  • William’s syndrome is characterized by distinctive “elfin” facial features, cardiovascular disease such as supravalvular aortic stenosis, hypercalcemia, developmental delays, and a unique personality profile that often includes being overly friendly.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. DiGeorge syndrome, also known as 22q11.2 deletion syndrome, includes features such as conotruncal congenital heart defects, hypocalcemia due to hypoparathyroidism, immune deficiencies, and other phenotypic features, but not typically the combination of features described in the question.

 

Option C. Prader-Willi syndrome is associated with hypotonia, obesity, hypogonadism, and mild to moderate intellectual disability. Coarse facial features, hypercalcemia, and supravalvular aortic stenosis are not typical of this syndrome.

 

Option D. Angelman syndrome is characterized by severe intellectual disability, seizures, ataxic gait, and frequent laughter or smiling, but it is not associated with the specific constellation of symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • William’s syndrome is the most likely diagnosis in a child presenting with coarse facial features, hypercalcemia, and a cardiac murmur indicative of supravalvular aortic stenosis.
  • Other key features of Williams syndrome include a broad smile, outgoing personality, and stellate iris pattern.

choices.text: Toxic shock syndrome
Scarlet fever
Kawasaki disease
Stevens-Johnson syndrome

questions.text: A child presents with a five-day history of fever, conjunctivitis without pus, cervical lymphadenopathy larger than 1.5 cm, erythematous skin with desquamation, and inflammation of the oral mucosa including a strawberry tongue. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Kawasaki disease

 

  • Kawasaki disease is a medium vessel vasculitis that typically affects children.
  • The clinical presentation can include fever for at least five days, non-exudative conjunctivitis, erythema and desquamation of the extremities, oral mucosal changes including "strawberry tongue," and cervical lymphadenopathy, which fits the presentation described.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Toxic shock syndrome is associated with fever, rash, and multisystem involvement, typically in association with toxin-producing bacterial infections. It is often accompanied by hypotension and organ dysfunction, which are not described in the question.

 

Option B. Scarlet fever is associated with fever, a fine sandpaper-like rash, and "strawberry tongue." However, it does not typically present with unilateral cervical lymphadenopathy or the systemic vasculitis seen in the condition described.

 

Option D. Stevens-Johnson syndrome is a serious systemic reaction with extensive mucosal involvement and epidermal detachment, but it is not typically characterized by prolonged fever or unilateral cervical lymphadenopathy, as described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Kawasaki disease is characterized by a constellation of symptoms, including fever for at least five days, non-purulent conjunctivitis, rash, edema of the hands and feet, changes in the oral mucosa, and cervical lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic by his mother, who reports that he has had a fever, sore throat, and difficulty swallowing for the past two days. On examination, the child appears irritable and has multiple small vesicular lesions with erythematous bases on his soft palate and tonsillar pillars. No skin rash is noted. His immunizations are up to date, and there is no significant past medical history. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent of this child's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coxsackievirus A

 

  • Coxsackievirus A is the most common cause of herpangina, an illness characterized by fever, sore throat, and vesicular lesions on the oropharynx, particularly the soft palate.
  • It typically affects young children and is more common in the summer and fall.
  • To begin with, multiple small vesicles appear on the faucial pillars, tonsils, soft palate and uvula.
  • They rupture to form ulcers which are usually 2–4 mm in size, had a yellow base and red areola around them. They seldom persist beyond 1 week.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Herpes Simplex Virus Type 1 (HSV-1). HSV-1 typically causes oral herpes, characterized by cold sores or fever blisters around the mouth. While it can cause pharyngitis, the presentation is usually different from that of herpangina.

 

Option C. Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV). EBV is the causative agent of infectious mononucleosis. It can cause pharyngitis, fever, and lymphadenopathy, but the presence of palatal vesicles is not characteristic of EBV infection.

 

Option D.  Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV). Acute HIV infection can present with pharyngitis, but it is not typically associated with the vesicular lesions seen in herpangina. Moreover, the epidemiology (a young, otherwise healthy child) makes this a less likely option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Identify Coxsackievirus A as the most common causative agent of herpangina, which presents with fever, sore throat, and vesicular lesions on the oropharynx, especially in young children.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with significant hepatomegaly, inconclusive liver function tests, and no clear etiology on imaging is considered for further diagnostic evaluation. Among the following options, which is NOT a typical reason for performing a percutaneous liver biopsy in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Unexplained massive ascites

 

  • Unexplained massive ascites is not a typical indication for a percutaneous liver biopsy primarily due to the increased risk of complications such as bleeding and leakage of ascitic fluid through the biopsy site.
  • Percutaneous liver biopsy in the presence of significant ascites is generally avoided or approached with caution, and alternative diagnostic methods or different biopsy approaches (e.g., transjugular liver biopsy) might be considered to minimize risks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Unexplained hepatomegaly. This is a common indication for liver biopsy when the cause of liver enlargement cannot be determined through non-invasive means. A biopsy can help diagnose conditions like fatty liver disease, chronic hepatitis, or infiltrative diseases.

 

Option B. Unexplained splenomegaly. While splenomegaly itself may not directly indicate a liver biopsy, it often accompanies liver diseases such as cirrhosis, suggesting an underlying condition affecting the liver that may warrant a biopsy for diagnosis.

 

Option D. Fever of unknown origin. In certain contexts, especially when liver involvement is suspected in systemic diseases or infections that could contribute to a prolonged fever, a liver biopsy might be indicated to aid in the diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Unexplained hepatomegaly and potential liver involvement in systemic diseases may warrant a liver biopsy for diagnostic purposes, massive ascites represents a relative contraindication due to increased procedural risks.

choices.text: Harlequin colour change
Mongolion spot
None of the above

questions.text: A newborn is observed with tight, translucent skin resembling plastic wrap, which is suggestive of a collodion membrane. The infant’s skin barrier function is impaired, which of the following diagnoses is most consistent with this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Harlequin icthyosis

 

Option A:

 

Picture is a case of Harlequin icthyosis / colloidon baby

 

Harlequin icthyosis, especially when referred to in the neonatal period as a "collodion baby," is characterized by a tight, shiny, translucent membrane that covers the skin and then peels off. It is associated with defects in skin barrier function and lipid transport and is typically inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Harlequin colour change is a condition often seen in newborns characterized by temporary colour changes, where half of the skin turns red while the other half turns pale. It is not associated with the collodion membrane.

 

Option C. Mongolian spots are congenital dermal melanocytosis, presenting as blue or greyish pigmentation, commonly found on the back or buttocks of infants. It does not present with the membrane-like skin changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The newborn in the picture is most likely a "Harlequin icthyosis," a term used for neonates born with ichthyosis vulgaris, characterized by a tight, shiny membrane that covers the skin and results from defects in skin development and lipid transport.
  • This condition is typically inherited in an autosomal recessive manner.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman visits your clinic for a consultation regarding her chronic pain management. She has a history of rheumatoid arthritis and has tried various over-the-counter medications, but with little relief. You consider prescribing a more potent medication that falls under a specific drug schedule, which mandates that it should only be dispensed with a prescription from a registered medical practitioner due to its potential for adverse effects and necessity for medical supervision. Which of the following drug schedules includes medications that should only be sold on the prescription of a registered medical practitioner?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Schedule H drugs

 

  • Schedule H drugs are a category of prescription drugs in some countries' drug regulation systems that are not to be sold without a prescription from a registered medical practitioner.
  • These drugs include those that can cause significant potential harm if used without adequate medical supervision, have a high potential for abuse, or are used to treat serious medical conditions.
  • The regulation helps ensure that these medications are used safely and effectively, minimizing the risk of adverse effects and misuse.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Schedule X drugs also require a prescription and are under even stricter control due to their high potential for abuse. However, the question specifically asks for the category that broadly encompasses prescription-only medications, making Schedule H a more fitting choice.

 

Option C. Schedule J drugs typically include substances that are not to be used as ingredients in pharmaceuticals and are not relevant to the context of prescription-only medications.

 

Option D. Schedule Y drugs are related to the clinical trial and regulatory approval process of drugs in some countries, not to the prescription requirements for dispensing existing medications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The question is designed to test the understanding of drug scheduling systems and their implications for clinical practice, particularly regarding which medications require a prescription from a registered medical practitioner.
  • It emphasizes the importance of adhering to legal and regulatory frameworks in prescribing medications, ensuring patient safety, and the effective use of pharmacological interventions in treatment plans.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency department with a swollen, red, and painful right lower leg. He mentions a minor abrasion he sustained while gardening a week ago. On examination, the area is warm to the touch, and there are purulent drainage and surrounding cellulitis. His temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F). Given the clinical presentation and the increasing prevalence of antibiotic-resistant organisms, you suspect a methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infection. You decide to initiate antibiotic therapy and recall that one of the following cephalosporins has activity against MRSA. Which cephalosporin would be most appropriate for this suspected infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ceftobiprole

 

  • Ceftobiprole is a broad-spectrum cephalosporin with activity against MRSA.
  • It is one of the few cephalosporins that can target MRSA effectively due to its ability to bind to modified penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs) that are present in MRSA strains.
  • This makes it a suitable choice for treating infections suspected to be caused by MRSA, in settings where this antibiotic is available and its use is indicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin widely used for various bacterial infections, but it lacks efficacy against MRSA.

 

Option B. Ceftazidime is a third-generation cephalosporin that has excellent activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa but does not have activity against MRSA.

 

Option C. Cefuroxime is a second-generation cephalosporin with a broader spectrum of activity than first-generation cephalosporins but is not effective against MRSA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The question is designed to test knowledge of antibiotic selection, specifically within the class of cephalosporins, for infections caused by resistant bacteria such as MRSA.
  • Understanding the spectrum of activity of different cephalosporins is crucial for effective and appropriate antibiotic therapy, especially in the context of increasing antibiotic resistance.

questions.text: A 25-year-old basketball player presents to the clinic after experiencing a painful "pop" in his knee during a game, followed by swelling and instability. Physical examination reveals a positive pivot shift test. The physician considers the structures that might be injured to account for this clinical finding. A positive pivot shift test in the knee is indicative of an injury to which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL)

 

  • Painful "pop" in knee during sports is a classic symptom of a ligamentous rupture, particularly the ACL.
  • Swelling and instability are also common signs of acute ligamentous injury.
  • The pivot shift test is a specific physical examination manoeuvre used to assess the integrity of the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) in the knee. 
  • It evaluates the amount of anterolateral rotatory instability.
  • It is the most specific and sensitive clinical test for an ACL rupture.
  • A positive pivot shift test, which indicates a momentary subluxation of the tibia on the femur followed by a reduction, is highly suggestive of an ACL tear. 
  • The ACL is crucial for maintaining the stability of the knee, especially in rotational and anterior-posterior movements. 
  • An injury to the ACL can lead to a sensation of instability or giving way, especially during activities that involve pivoting or sudden changes in direction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Posterior cruciate ligament (PCL).PCL injuries typically result in posterior instability. Injuries to the PCL typically present with a positive posterior drawer test or posterior sag sign, not a positive pivot shift test. The PCL is responsible for preventing posterior displacement of the tibia relative to the femur. 

 

Option C. Medial meniscus. While meniscal injuries can contribute to knee pain and instability, a positive pivot shift test is not indicative of a meniscal injury. Meniscus tears can cause pain, swelling, and mechanical symptoms like locking or clicking, but they do not primarily cause the type of rotatory instability. Meniscal injuries are more likely to be identified with the McMurray test or joint line tenderness. 

 

Option D. Lateral meniscus. Similar to the medial meniscus, lateral meniscus injuries do not typically present with a positive pivot shift test. The presentation and diagnosis of lateral meniscal injuries involve other clinical findings and tests. A lateral meniscus tear can sometimes accompany an ACL tear, but it is not the primary structure assessed by the pivot shift.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A positive pivot shift test is the most specific and sensitive clinical test for an ACL rupture. 
  • It directly demonstrates the anterolateral rotatory instability caused by an incompetent ACL.

choices.text: The patient can present with diabetic ketoacidosis.
The condition can be treated with oral glucose-lowering agents once the patient is stabilized.
Positive autoimmune markers are typically present in this type of diabetes.
Autoimmune markers are typically absent in this type of diabetes.

questions.text: A 45-year-old recently diagnosed diabetic male presents with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), showing high blood glucose and urinary ketones. With a BMI of 29 kg/m² and no autoimmune history, which statement about ketosis-prone type 2 DM is incorrect in this context?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Positive autoimmune markers are typically present in this type of diabetes

 

  • Ketosis-prone type 2 diabetes mellitus, also known as Flatbush diabetes, is characterized by the acute onset of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) in individuals who may not have a prior history of diabetes.
  • Unlike type 1 diabetes, which involves autoimmune destruction of insulin-producing beta cells and is often associated with positive autoimmune markers (such as anti-GAD antibodies), ketosis-prone type 2 diabetes typically does not have these autoimmune markers.
  • Patients with ketosis-prone type 2 diabetes often have features of type 2 diabetes, such as obesity or a strong family history of diabetes, and may not require lifelong insulin therapy.
  • They can often be managed with oral glucose-lowering agents after the initial episode of DKA is resolved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The patient can present with diabetic ketoacidosis. Patients with ketosis-prone type 2 DM can indeed present with DKA, which might be their first manifestation of diabetes.

 

Option B. The condition can be treated with oral glucose-lowering agents once the patient is stabilized. After the acute episode of DKA is treated, patients with ketosis-prone type 2 DM can often be managed with oral glucose-lowering agents, reflecting their type 2 diabetes pathophysiology.

 

Option D. Autoimmune markers are typically absent in this type of diabetes. The statement that autoimmune markers are typically absent in ketosis-prone type 2 DM is correct. This distinguishes it from type 1 diabetes, where autoimmune markers are usually present.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The educational objective of this question is to understand the characteristics of ketosis-prone type 2 diabetes mellitus, particularly distinguishing it from type 1 diabetes.
  • It emphasizes that ketosis-prone type 2 diabetes can present with DKA, similar to type 1 diabetes, but lacks autoimmune markers and can often be managed with oral glucose-lowering agents after stabilization from the acute episode, reflecting its type 2 diabetes pathophysiology.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with complaints of difficulty swallowing and a sensation of food getting stuck in his throat. Upon further examination, a biopsy is taken from the affected area of the oesophagus, revealing changes in the epithelial tissue. Histological examination of the biopsy shows a type of epithelium that is multilayered but lacks keratinization, typically found in areas requiring a protective barrier that remains moist. Based on the histological findings, which type of epithelium is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium

 

  • Non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium is found in areas that need protection from mechanical abrasion but must also remain moist, such as the oral cavity, pharynx, oesophagus, and the anal canal.
  • This type of epithelium is multilayered, which helps in protection, but does not have a layer of keratin on its surface, allowing it to stay moist.
  • The patient's symptoms and the histological findings of the oesophagus biopsy suggest that the affected epithelium is non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium, which is consistent with the location and the nature of the epithelium involved in the pathology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Keratinized stratified squamous epithelium. This type of epithelium has a layer of keratin on its surface and is found in areas exposed to the external environment, such as the skin. The keratin layer provides a waterproof barrier, which is not needed in the internal cavities like the esophagus.

 

Option C. Transitional epithelium. Also known as urothelium, this type of epithelium lines the urinary bladder, ureters, and part of the urethra. It is specialized to stretch and accommodate fluctuations in volume in the urinary tract, which is not relevant to the esophagus.

 

Option D. Simple columnar epithelium. This type of epithelium is typically found in areas of absorption or secretion, such as the stomach, small intestines, and some parts of the colon. It consists of a single layer of column-shaped cells, which does not match the description of the biopsy from the patient's esophagus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • This question assesses the learner's ability to identify non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium based on its location and functional requirements.
  • The correct answer, non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium, is found in the esophagus and is adapted to provide protection without a keratin layer, allowing the tissue to remain moist, which is essential for its function in the esophagus.
  • Understanding the differences between various types of epithelial tissues, such as keratinized vs non-keratinized and their locations and functions in the body, is crucial for diagnosing and managing esophageal and other epithelial-related diseases.

choices.text: Defective osteoclastic resorption of uncalcified osteoid and cartilage

questions.text: A pediatrician is reviewing a case of a child with bowing of the legs, delayed growth, and a history of prolonged nutritional deficiencies. The child's laboratory tests reveal low levels of vitamin D, calcium, and phosphate. Based on the clinical presentation and laboratory findings, the pediatrician considers a diagnosis that involves a fundamental defect in bone metabolism. Understanding the underlying pathology of this condition is crucial for initiating the appropriate treatment. The basic pathological defect in rickets is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Defective osteoclastic resorption of uncalcified osteoid and cartilage

 

  • Rickets is primarily characterized by a defect in the mineralization of bone due to inadequate levels of calcium, phosphate, or vitamin D.
  • This results in an accumulation of unmineralized bone matrix (osteoid) and cartilage, particularly at the growth plates (physes) of long bones, leading to softening and deformation of bones.
  • The key pathological process in rickets involves defective mineralization, rather than a specific dysfunction of osteoblasts or osteoclasts.
  • The osteoclasts are involved in the resorption of bone tissue, and while their function may be indirectly affected in rickets, the core issue lies with the failure to properly mineralize new osteoid and cartilage, not with the resorption process itself.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased osteoblastic activity. While osteoblastic activity may be altered in rickets, the primary issue is not a decrease in their activity but rather a failure in the mineralization process of the osteoid they produce.

 

Option B. Non-functional osteoclast. Non-functional osteoclasts are not the primary defect in rickets. Osteoclasts are responsible for bone resorption, and their dysfunction would lead to different clinical manifestations.

 

Option D. Defective proliferation of physis. Although the growth plates are affected in rickets, leading to abnormalities such as bowing of the legs, the fundamental defect is in the mineralization process, not merely in the proliferation of the physis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The educational objective of this question is to identify the fundamental pathological defect in rickets as the defective mineralization of osteoid and cartilage, leading to an accumulation of uncalcified bone matrix.
  • This understanding is crucial for diagnosing and treating rickets, which typically involves supplementation with vitamin D, calcium, and phosphate to address the underlying deficiencies and correct bone mineralization.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe abdominal pain. The pain is described as sharp, periumbilical, and radiating to the back. He has a past medical history of atrial fibrillation for which he is on anticoagulation therapy. His vital signs are stable upon examination, but his abdomen is tender in the periumbilical area with some guarding. An urgent CT angiogram of the abdomen is performed, which reveals occlusion of a major abdominal artery. Based on the patient's presentation and imaging findings, which artery is most likely occluded?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superior mesenteric artery

 

  • The superior mesenteric artery (SMA) is the most likely artery to be occluded in this patient, given the sudden onset of severe, sharp periumbilical pain radiating to the back.
  • The SMA supplies blood to the midgut, which includes the lower duodenum, jejunum, ileum, cecum, ascending colon, and most of the transverse colon.
  • Acute occlusion, possibly due to an embolism (especially in a patient with a history of atrial fibrillation), can lead to ischemia of these regions, causing severe abdominal pain.
  • The location of the pain corresponds to the distribution of the SMA, and the patient's anticoagulation therapy may have been insufficient to prevent such an embolic event.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Celiac trunk. Occlusion of the celiac trunk would predominantly affect the foregut, leading to pain in the upper abdomen. The presentation would likely include the stomach, duodenum, liver, and spleen, not the periumbilical region.

 

Option C. Inferior mesenteric artery. This artery supplies the hindgut, including the distal transverse colon, descending colon, sigmoid colon, and rectum. Occlusion would typically cause pain in the lower abdomen and might be associated with changes in bowel habits or blood in the stool, not the acute presentation described.

 

Option D. Renal artery. Occlusion of the renal artery would primarily affect the kidneys, potentially leading to flank pain, hematuria, or acute kidney injury. It would not typically cause periumbilical pain or the gastrointestinal symptoms seen in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The objective of this question is to identify the clinical presentation and implications of acute superior mesenteric artery (SMA) occlusion.
  • Understanding the anatomical distribution of the SMA and recognizing the typical symptoms of its occlusion, such as severe periumbilical pain radiating to the back, are crucial for prompt diagnosis and treatment.
  • This knowledge aids in distinguishing SMA occlusion from other vascular events affecting different abdominal organs, ensuring appropriate and targeted therapeutic interventions.

choices.text: Sensitivity of fever for appendicitis is 21/49
Specificity of fever for appendicitis is 42/70
Positive predictive value of fever for appendicitis is 21/30
Specificity of fever for appendicitis varies with prevalence

questions.text: In an emergency department, a study is conducted on patients presenting with abdominal pain to determine the diagnostic utility of fever (>37.5°C) for acute appendicitis. It is found that 30% have acute appendicitis, 70% of those with appendicitis have a fever, and 40% of those without appendicitis also have a fever. Based on this information, which of the following is true about using fever as a diagnostic marker for appendicitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Specificity of fever for appendicitis is 42/70

 

  • Specificity is calculated as the number of true negatives (those without the condition and test negative) divided by the total number of actual negatives.
  • Here, 60% of the 70 patients without appendicitis do not have a fever, resulting in 42 true negatives out of 70, giving a specificity of 42/70.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sensitivity of fever for appendicitis is 21/49. Incorrect because sensitivity is the true positives divided by the total with the condition, which isn't represented by 21/49.

 

Option C. Positive Predictive Value (PPV) of fever for appendicitis is 21/30. Incorrect as PPV is the true positives divided by all positive tests (true positives + false positives), not 21/30.

 

Option D. Specificity of fever for appendicitis varies with prevalence. Incorrect because specificity is a characteristic of the test and does not vary with disease prevalence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Specificity of a screening test is the ability of a test to detect: True negatives
  • Sensitivity of a screening test is the ability of a test to detect: True positives
  • Usefulness of a screening test is given by: Sensitivity
  • Statistical index of diagnostic accuracy: Sensitivity
  • Out of those shown positive by a screening test in a population, those who actually have the disease, this is: PPV of a screening test
  • Out of those shown negative by a screening test in a population, those who actually don’t have the disease, this is: NPV of a screening test

questions.text: Which of these surgeries may be beneficial in unilateral vocal cord palsy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Type I Thyroplasty

 

  • Unilateral adductor palsy of the vocal cord can lead to a gap between the vocal cords during phonation, resulting in voice difficulties (breathy voice).
  • Type I thyroplasty is a surgical procedure that involves the insertion of an implant to medialize (move closer to the midline) the affected vocal cord.
  • This medialization helps improve vocal cords approximation and voice quality in individuals with unilateral vocal cord palsy.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Kashima’s surgery (Posterior transverse cordotomy) is a well-known surgical procedure for addressing bilateral vocal cord palsy.

 

Option C. Woodman’s surgery is not a recognized surgical procedure for addressing this condition.

 

Option D. Total laryngectomy is a surgical procedure that involves the removal of the entire larynx. It is typically performed for more severe laryngeal conditions, such as advanced laryngeal cancer, and is not a treatment for unilateral adductor palsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Type I thyroplasty may be beneficial in addressing unilateral vocal cord palsy by improving phonation.

choices.text: Pancreaticoduodenectomy
Longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy
ERCP and sphincterotomy
Coring of pancreas head

questions.text: An alcoholic patient presented with features of chronic pancreatitis with recurrent attacks and has a 10 mm dilatation of the pancreatic duct with intraductal calculi present. Which of the following is the surgery of choice?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy

 

  • In the given scenario of dilated pancreatic duct with stones, a drainage procedure in the form of longitudinal pancreatico-jejunostomy (Peusthow) is preferred.

 

Other options:

 

Option A and D. Pancreaticoduodenectomy (Whipple’s) and Coring of pancreas head may be if inflammation is limited to head of pancreas alone.

 

Option C. ERCP and sphincterotomy. ERCP may aid removal of pancreatic calculi but is not a long term solution.

 

CHRONIC PANCREATITIS: Irreversible damage to architecture of pancreas

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In a case of dilated pancreatic duct with stones, a drainage procedure in the form of longitudinal pancreatico-jejunostomy (Peusthow) is preferred.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to his primary care physician with complaints of discomfort and mild pain in the upper part of his neck when swallowing. He reports that this has been ongoing for several months and seems to be worsening. The patient also notes that he occasionally regurgitates undigested food shortly after eating, which is particularly distressing during social meals. He denies any significant weight loss, changes in appetite, or gastrointestinal bleeding. His past medical history is unremarkable, and he is not on any regular medications. Physical examination, including a neck examination, is unremarkable. Based on the patient's history and clinical presentation, which of the following is the most likely etiology of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zenker’s diverticulum

 

  • Zenker's diverticulum is an outpouching of the pharyngeal mucosa that occurs at the junction of the oropharynx and esophagus (Killian's triangle).
  • This condition is more common in older adults and can lead to symptoms such as dysphagia, regurgitation of undigested food, coughing, and neck pain, particularly during swallowing.
  • The regurgitation of undigested food, as described by the patient, is a hallmark of this condition, as the diverticulum can collect food particles that are later expelled.
  • The diagnosis is often confirmed through a barium swallow study or esophagoscopy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mallory-Weiss Tears. These are longitudinal lacerations at the gastroesophageal junction, usually caused by forceful or prolonged vomiting. Patients typically present with hematemesis (vomiting blood) rather than regurgitation of undigested food.

 

Option C. Schatzki Rings. A Schatzki ring is a narrowing of the lower esophagus that can cause intermittent dysphagia, especially for solid foods. Patients usually do not experience regurgitation of undigested food shortly after eating, which distinguishes this from Zenker’s diverticulum.

 

Option D. Traction Diverticula. These are typically mid-esophageal diverticula caused by external traction from fibrotic mediastinal lymph nodes. They are less common and usually asymptomatic or cause vague esophageal symptoms, not specifically regurgitation of undigested food soon after eating.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • When a patient presents with symptoms of dysphagia and regurgitation of undigested food without associated vomiting, Zenker’s diverticulum should be high on the differential diagnosis list.
  • This condition is characterized by the formation of a diverticulum at the pharyngoesophageal junction, which can trap food and lead to regurgitation.
  • Other conditions, such as Mallory-Weiss tears, Schatzki rings, and traction diverticula, affect the esophagus differently and present with distinct clinical features that help differentiate them from Zenker’s diverticulum.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male software developer presents to your clinic complaining of seasonal allergic rhinitis symptoms, including sneezing, nasal congestion, and itchy eyes. He reports that these symptoms significantly impact his work performance, especially during the spring. The patient is seeking a medication that can alleviate his symptoms without causing drowsiness or impairing his cognitive function, as his job requires high levels of concentration and attention to detail. Considering his need for a non-sedating antihistamine, which of the following medications would be most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fexofenadine

 

  • Fexofenadine is a second-generation antihistamine known for its minimal or no CNS depressant activity.
  • Unlike first-generation antihistamines, which readily cross the blood-brain barrier and can cause significant sedation and drowsiness, fexofenadine has a lower affinity for the central H1 receptors, making it an ideal choice for patients who require relief from allergic symptoms without the sedative effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Promethazine is a first-generation antihistamine with significant sedative effects, making it unsuitable for patients who need to maintain alertness and cognitive function.

 

Option B. Meclizine is another first-generation antihistamine primarily used to treat nausea and motion sickness, and it also has sedative properties.

 

Option C. Cinnarizine, also a first-generation antihistamine, is used for its anti-vertigo and antiemetic properties but can cause sedation and impair cognitive function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The question aims to test the knowledge of the side effect profiles of different generations of antihistamines, specifically their potential for CNS depressant activity.
  • Understanding the pharmacologic differences between first- and second-generation antihistamines is crucial for selecting the appropriate medication based on the patient's needs, especially when avoiding sedation is a priority.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents, who are concerned about his frequent and severe bacterial infections. His medical history is notable for multiple hospital admissions due to bacterial infections that required intravenous antibiotics for resolution. A detailed workup indicates a defect in the patient's ability to generate reactive oxygen species within phagocytes. Which of the following components is most likely deficient or dysfunctional in this patient's phagocytes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) NADPH oxidase

 

  • NADPH oxidase plays a crucial role in the innate immune system's ability to combat pathogens.
  • It is responsible for generating superoxide radicals by transferring electrons from NADPH inside the phagocyte to oxygen, creating a superoxide anion, a precursor to other reactive oxygen species (ROS).
  • These ROS are essential for the oxidative burst that phagocytes use to kill ingested pathogens.
  • A deficiency or dysfunction in NADPH oxidase leads to a condition known as Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD), characterized by recurrent, severe infections with bacteria and fungi due to the inability of phagocytes to produce ROS necessary for killing pathogens.
  • The clinical presentation of frequent and severe bacterial infections in this young patient strongly suggests a diagnosis of CGD, likely due to NADPH oxidase deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myeloperoxidase. This enzyme is involved in the conversion of hydrogen peroxide to hypochlorous acid within phagocytes. While myeloperoxidase deficiency can lead to increased susceptibility to infections, it typically does not result in the same severity of recurrent infections as seen in CGD.

 

Option C. Catalase. Catalase breaks down hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen. Its deficiency is not typically associated with an increased risk of severe bacterial infections. Pathogens that produce their own catalase can pose a problem in CGD because they neutralize the less effective ROS, but catalase deficiency in human cells is not the primary issue in this context.

 

Option D. Superoxide dismutase. This enzyme converts superoxide radicals into hydrogen peroxide and is not directly involved in the oxidative burst mechanism of killing pathogens. Deficiencies are more associated with neurological conditions than with increased susceptibility to infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The question aims to highlight the importance of NADPH oxidase in the immune response, particularly in the oxidative burst mechanism of phagocytes that is crucial for killing pathogens.
  • It underscores the clinical presentation and implications of NADPH oxidase deficiency, leading to Chronic Granulomatous Disease, which is characterized by recurrent, severe infections. Understanding the role of various components in the immune system's response to pathogens is essential for diagnosing and managing immune deficiencies.

choices.text: Inhibition of bacterial cell wall synthesis
Disruption of bacterial protein synthesis

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with no significant past medical history presents to the clinic with complaints of fever, dysuria, and increased frequency of urination for the past two days. On examination, her temperature is 101.3°F, and her physical examination is unremarkable except for mild suprapubic tenderness. Urinalysis reveals pyuria and bacteriuria. A urine culture is obtained, and empirical antibiotic therapy is initiated. Given the patient's symptoms and initial urinalysis findings, Cotrimoxazole (TMP-SMX) is chosen as the empirical treatment. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of action of Cotrimoxazole in treating this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inhibition of dihydrofolate reductase

 

  • Cotrimoxazole, also known as Trimethoprim-Sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX), acts by inhibiting two consecutive steps in the bacterial synthesis of tetrahydrofolic acid, which is essential for the synthesis of purines and hence for the synthesis of DNA.
  • Sulfamethoxazole inhibits dihydropteroate synthase, while Trimethoprim inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, effectively halting the production of tetrahydrofolic acid.
  • This dual blockade is what makes Cotrimoxazole an effective bacteriostatic agent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibition of bacterial cell wall synthesis is the mechanism of action of antibiotics such as penicillins and cephalosporins, not Cotrimoxazole.

 

Option C. Disruption of bacterial protein synthesis is characteristic of antibiotics like tetracyclines and aminoglycosides.

 

Option D. Inhibition of DNA gyrase is the mechanism of action of fluoroquinolones, not Cotrimoxazole.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The question aims to test the understanding of the mechanism of action of Cotrimoxazole (Trimethoprim-Sulfamethoxazole), a commonly used antibiotic for urinary tract infections.
  • Cotrimoxazole works by inhibiting two consecutive steps in the bacterial synthesis of tetrahydrofolic acid, essential for DNA synthesis, making it an effective treatment for bacterial infections.
  • Understanding the specific actions of antibiotics is crucial for their effective and appropriate use in clinical practice.

questions.text: During a medical school immunology course, a student is tasked with presenting on various vaccination strategies used to prevent infectious diseases. One segment of the presentation focuses on the prevention of Hepatitis B, a significant global health concern due to its potential to cause chronic liver disease and hepatocellular carcinoma. The student explores the development, mechanism, and efficacy of the Hepatitis B vaccine. Based on current vaccination technology and the nature of the Hepatitis B vaccine, which of the following descriptions best characterizes the Hepatitis B vaccine?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Recombinant DNA vaccine

 

  • The Hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant DNA vaccine, which means it is produced through recombinant DNA technology.
  • This technology involves inserting the gene for the hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) into yeast cells, which then produce the antigen.
  • The antigen is purified and used as the active component of the vaccine, stimulating the immune system to produce protective antibodies against Hepatitis B virus (HBV) without causing the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Edible vaccine. Edible vaccines are a research area involving the introduction of selected genes into plants, allowing the edible parts to produce the antigenic proteins. This concept is not applicable to the current Hepatitis B vaccine.

 

Option C. Nuclear transformation. This term does not specifically apply to vaccine technology. In the context of genetics, transformation refers to the alteration of a cell's genetic material through the uptake of foreign DNA.

 

Option D. RNA vaccine. RNA vaccines, such as some COVID-19 vaccines, use messenger RNA (mRNA) to instruct cells to produce a viral protein that elicits an immune response. The Hepatitis B vaccine does not utilize RNA technology; instead, it is based on recombinant DNA technology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant DNA vaccine, the first of its kind approved for human use.

choices.text: It begins as a continuation of sigmoid sinus
Superior bulb lodges in the jugular fossa of temporal bone
Inferior bulb lies beneath the suprasternal space
Common carotid artery lies medial to it

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about the pointed structure in the below image.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inferior bulb lies beneath the suprasternal space

 

  • The statement about the inferior bulb lying beneath the suprasternal space is incorrect because the inferior bulb of the internal jugular vein is located at the root of the neck and does not extend down into the suprasternal space.
  • The inferior bulb is typically found at the level where the internal jugular vein joins with the subclavian vein to form the brachiocephalic vein, which is above the suprasternal space.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It begins as a continuation of sigmoid sinus. This statement is correct. The internal jugular vein begins at the base of the skull as a direct continuation of the sigmoid sinus, one of the dural venous sinuses that drain blood from the brain.

 

Option B. Superior bulb lodges in the jugular fossa of temporal bone. This is also correct. The superior bulb of the internal jugular vein is located at the jugular foramen, where it exits the skull. The jugular fossa is part of the temporal bone that accommodates the jugular foramen.

 

Option D. Common carotid artery lies medial to it. This statement is accurate. In the neck, the common carotid artery is typically located medial to the internal jugular vein. This anatomical relationship is a key landmark in surgical procedures and medical imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The question aims to assess the understanding of the anatomy of the internal jugular vein, particularly its relationship with surrounding structures and its anatomical course.
  • It emphasizes the importance of recognizing the correct anatomical landmarks and relationships, such as the origin of the internal jugular vein, the location of its bulbs, and its spatial relationship with the common carotid artery, which are crucial for accurate diagnosis, surgical planning, and interventions involving the neck and head regions.

 

Ref: IB Singh, Textbook of Anatomy, vol. 3, Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy, 7th edition, page no. 341

questions.text: A neonatologist evaluates a newborn with notable physical findings including limb hypoplasia, scarring on the hands, and chorioretinitis. The mother recalls experiencing a vesicular rash during the second trimester of her pregnancy. These clinical manifestations in the neonate are concerning for an intrauterine infection acquired from the mother. Given the maternal history and the neonate's clinical presentation, which of the following intrauterine infections is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fetal varicella syndrome

 

  • Fetal varicella syndrome, caused by maternal infection with the varicella-zoster virus (VZV) during pregnancy, can lead to a range of congenital abnormalities in the neonate.
  • The characteristic features include limb hypoplasia, cicatricial skin lesions (scarring), ocular abnormalities such as chorioretinitis, and neurological disorders.
  • The mother's history of a vesicular rash during pregnancy, consistent with varicella (chickenpox), strongly suggests fetal varicella syndrome as the cause of the neonate's condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV). Neonatal HSV infection typically results from exposure to HSV during delivery, rather than intrauterine infection. It can cause severe neonatal illness, including encephalitis and disseminated disease, but it does not typically present with limb hypoplasia and cicatricial skin lesions.

 

Option B. Rubella. Congenital rubella syndrome can result in cataracts, cardiac defects, and hearing impairment, among other findings. While it can lead to ocular issues, the specific combination of limb hypoplasia, cicatricial lesions, and maternal vesicular rash is not characteristic of rubella.

 

Option C. Cytomegalovirus (CMV). CMV is the most common congenital viral infection and can cause a wide range of clinical manifestations, including hearing loss, microcephaly, and chorioretinitis. However, the presence of limb hypoplasia and cicatricial lesions, along with a maternal history of a vesicular rash, is more indicative of fetal varicella syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fetal varicella syndrome, resulting from maternal VZV infection during pregnancy, especially in the first or early second trimester, leads to developmental abnormalities like limb hypoplasia and chorioretinitis.
  • This is distinct from the effects of other infections during pregnancy, such as HSV, Rubella, or CMV, each causing different types of congenital abnormalities.

choices.text: Sign of recovery from spinal shock
Partial lesion of the spinal cord
Complete transection of the spinal cord
Incomplete transection of the spinal cord

questions.text: A patient with a recent spinal cord injury is being monitored for neurological signs to assess the extent of the injury and potential for recovery. Initially, the patient exhibited signs of spinal shock, characterized by a complete loss of reflexes, motor, sensory, and autonomic function below the level of injury. Over time, the medical team observes the return of the bulbocavernosus reflex, which involves a contraction of the anal sphincter in response to squeezing the glans penis or clitoris. The team considers the significance of this finding in the context of the patient's spinal cord injury. The return of the bulbocavernosus reflex in a patient with spinal shock indicates:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sign of recovery from spinal shock

 

  • The return of the bulbocavernosus reflex is a significant clinical sign indicating the resolution of spinal shock.
  • Spinal shock is a temporary condition that occurs following a spinal cord injury, characterized by flaccid paralysis, loss of reflex activity, and autonomic dysfunction below the level of injury.
  • The resolution of spinal shock is marked by the return of reflexes, starting with the bulbocavernosus reflex, which is one of the earliest reflexes to return.
  • This does not necessarily provide information about the completeness or incompleteness of the spinal cord lesion but rather indicates the transition out of the spinal shock phase and the potential for further neurological recovery or assessment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Partial lesion of the spinal cord. While the return of reflexes may suggest some level of preservation of neural pathways, the return of the bulbocavernosus reflex alone does not specifically indicate a partial lesion.

 

Option C. Complete transection of the spinal cord. The return of reflexes such as the bulbocavernosus reflex does not indicate the completeness or incompleteness of the transection. Complete transection might be suggested by other clinical findings and imaging.

 

Option D. Incomplete transection of the spinal cord. Similarly, while incomplete lesions may allow for more significant recovery of function, the return of the bulbocavernosus reflex specifically indicates the resolution of spinal shock rather than the degree of spinal cord injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The educational objective of this question is to understand that the return of the bulbocavernosus reflex is a clinical sign indicating the resolution of spinal shock following a spinal cord injury.
  • This finding is important for clinicians as it marks the end of the spinal shock phase, after which a more accurate neurological assessment can be made, and the extent of permanent injury can begin to be evaluated.

choices.text: Ampulla of Vater
Ligament of Treitz
Superior duodenal flexure
Ileocecal junction

questions.text: A 35-year-old man came with complaints of dark-colored stools to the OPD. After undergoing endoscopy, the patient was diagnosed with an upper GI bleed. Which of the following structures is used as a demarcation point to differentiate it from a lower GI bleed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ligament of Treitz

 

  • The ligament of Treitz is used as the demarcation point to differentiate between upper gastrointestinal bleeding and lower gastrointestinal bleeding.
  • It is a part of the duodenojejunal junction.
  • Upper GI bleeding refers to bleeding proximal to the ligament of Treitz, and lower GI bleeding refers to bleeding distal to the ligament of Treitz.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ampulla of Vater. The ampulla of Vater is the point where the pancreatic duct and common bile duct converge and enter the second part of the duodenum. It is an essential structure for the drainage of both bile and pancreatic enzymes into the duodenum. It is not used as a demarcation point for differentiating between upper and lower gastrointestinal bleeding.

 

Option C. Superior duodenal flexure. The superior duodenal flexure is the bend in the duodenum as it transitions from the first part (horizontal) to the second part (descending).

 

Option D. Ileocecal junction. The ileocecal junction is the point where the ileum meets the cecum. The ileocecal valve is present here, preventing the reflux of colonic contents into the ileum. While it's an important anatomical landmark in the gastrointestinal tract, it's not used as the demarcation point for differentiating between upper and lower gastrointestinal bleeding.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The ligament of Treitz is used as the demarcation point to differentiate between upper gastrointestinal bleeding and lower gastrointestinal bleeding

choices.text: A healthy 30-year-old man needing an inguinal hernia repair
A 45-year-old woman with well-controlled diabetes requiring a laparoscopic cholecystectomy
An elderly woman needing a cataract operation who lives with a mentally challenged caretaker
A 25-year-old woman requiring diagnostic laparoscopy for endometriosis

questions.text: Which of the following patients would NOT be typically considered as an ideal candidate for day care surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) An elderly woman needing a cataract operation who lives with a mentally challenged caretaker

 

  • This patient may not be an ideal candidate for day care surgery because, even though the procedure is typically done as a day surgery, her postoperative care could be compromised due to her caretaker's inability to adequately provide for her needs at home after the procedure.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. A healthy 30-year-old man needing an inguinal hernia repair. This patient would be an ideal candidate for day care surgery as he is young, healthy, and the procedure he needs is commonly performed as an outpatient procedure.

 

Option B. A 45-year-old woman with well-controlled diabetes requiring a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. While she has diabetes, it is well-controlled, and she is otherwise healthy. The procedure she requires is often performed on an outpatient basis, making her a suitable candidate for day care surgery.

 

Option D. A 25-year-old woman requiring diagnostic laparoscopy for endometriosis. This is a common outpatient procedure and she is young and presumably healthy, making her a good candidate for day care surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ideal candidates for day care surgery, also known as outpatient surgery, are typically individuals who are in good general health, have stable medical conditions, and meet specific criteria.
  • These candidates should be mentally and emotionally stable, have a responsible adult to accompany them home, and follow preoperative instructions.
  • They should undergo relatively straightforward and low-risk elective procedures, with realistic expectations about surgery and recovery.
  • Individualized assessments by the surgical team, including the surgeon and anesthesiologist, prioritize patient safety and minimize risks.

choices.text: Superior Pulmonary Vein
Inferior Pulmonary Vein

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with acute shortness of breath and chest pain. A CT angiogram of the chest is ordered to rule out a pulmonary embolism. The radiologist notes an anomaly in the vascular structures of the lungs and points out an enlarged vein draining into the left atrium. This vein is primarily responsible for carrying oxygenated blood from the lower lobes of the lungs back to the heart. Which of the following veins is most likely being described?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inferior Pulmonary Vein

 

  • The inferior pulmonary vein is responsible for draining oxygenated blood from the lower lobes of the lungs back to the left atrium of the heart.
  • Each lung has an inferior pulmonary vein, and these veins are crucial for the pulmonary circulation, ensuring the return of oxygenated blood to the heart for systemic distribution.
  • The enlargement or anomaly of the inferior pulmonary vein could be indicative of various pulmonary or cardiac conditions, and its identification is key in diagnosing and managing respiratory and cardiovascular diseases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior Pulmonary Vein. This vein drains oxygenated blood from the upper lobes of the lungs to the left atrium. While it also plays a crucial role in pulmonary circulation, the question specifically mentions the vein responsible for draining the lower lobes, which points to the inferior pulmonary vein.

 

Option C. Pulmonary Artery. The pulmonary artery carries deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle of the heart to the lungs for oxygenation. It is not involved in draining blood from the lungs back to the heart, thus not the correct answer in this context.

 

Option D. Azygos Vein. The azygos vein is part of the systemic venous system, draining deoxygenated blood from the posterior walls of the thorax and abdomen into the superior vena cava. It is not directly involved in pulmonary circulation and does not drain blood from the lungs to the heart.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • This question aims to assess the learner's understanding of the pulmonary venous system, particularly the role of the inferior pulmonary vein in draining oxygenated blood from the lower lobes of the lungs to the left atrium.
  • Recognizing the anatomy and function of the pulmonary veins is essential in the diagnosis and treatment of pulmonary and cardiovascular conditions, as anomalies in these veins can have significant clinical implications.
  • Understanding these vascular structures also aids in the accurate interpretation of imaging studies, such as CT angiograms, which are pivotal in diagnosing conditions like pulmonary embolism.

questions.text: A 21-year-old primigravida is at her 21-week prenatal visit, expressing concern about not having felt fetal movements, often referred to as "quickening." Quickening is typically perceived by first-time mothers around 18-22 weeks of gestation. She is anxious, seeking reassurance and understanding of potential reasons for this delay. Consider the following potential reasons for her not perceiving fetal movements yet, and identify which one is not a plausible cause.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Multiple pregnancy

 

  • Multiple pregnancies are usually associated with more noticeable fetal movements earlier in the pregnancy due to the presence of more than one fetus.
  • Therefore, multiple pregnancy would not be a reason for a woman not to perceive quickening by 21 weeks.
  • In fact, women with multiple pregnancies might perceive fetal movements earlier than those with a singleton pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maternal obesity. Increased maternal adipose tissue can dampen the sensation of fetal movements, making it more difficult for an obese mother to perceive quickening as early as a mother with less body fat.

 

Option C. Anterior placenta. When the placenta is positioned at the front of the uterus (anteriorly), it can act as a cushion between the fetus and the abdominal wall. This placement can reduce the intensity of fetal movements felt by the mother, potentially delaying the perception of quickening.

 

Option D. Fetal demise. Absence of fetal movements can be an indicator of fetal demise. If the fetus has passed away, there would be no movements for the mother to perceive. This is a serious condition that requires immediate medical attention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • This question assesses the understanding of factors that can influence the perception of fetal movements or "quickening" in pregnancy.
  • It's important to recognize that while maternal obesity and an anterior placenta can delay the perception of fetal movements, and fetal demise can altogether stop them, a multiple pregnancy typically results in earlier and possibly more pronounced fetal movements.
  • Understanding these factors is crucial for assessing fetal well-being and providing appropriate reassurance and care to pregnant women.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician due to episodes of hypoglycemia, especially during periods of fasting. Laboratory tests reveal low blood sugar levels and elevated levels of dicarboxylic acids in the urine. The child appears lethargic and irritable during these episodes but recovers quickly after being fed. The pediatrician suspects a disorder in fatty acid metabolism. Which of the following enzymatic deficiencies is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acyl-CoA dehydrogenase

 

  • The correct answer is Option A) Acyl-CoA dehydrogenase.
  • The patient's symptoms of hypoglycemia during fasting and the presence of elevated dicarboxylic acids in the urine suggest a deficiency in fatty acid oxidation.
  • Acyl-CoA dehydrogenase is crucial in the β-oxidation pathway of fatty acid metabolism.
  • A deficiency in this enzyme can lead to an inability to break down fatty acids into acetyl-CoA, leading to hypoglycemia during fasting when the body relies on fatty acids for energy.
  • The accumulation of partially oxidized fatty acids results in elevated dicarboxylic acids in the urine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Citrate synthase. This enzyme is involved in the citric acid cycle, not directly in fatty acid oxidation. A deficiency would affect the energy production from all acetyl-CoA sources, not specifically during fasting.

 

Option C. Hexokinase. This enzyme catalyses the phosphorylation of glucose to glucose-6-phosphate, the first step of glycolysis. A deficiency would impair glucose utilization but is not related to the symptoms of fasting hypoglycemia and elevated dicarboxylic acids indicative of a fatty acid oxidation disorder.

 

Option D. Pyruvate carboxylase. This enzyme is involved in gluconeogenesis. While a deficiency can lead to hypoglycemia, it would not explain the elevated levels of dicarboxylic acids in the urine, which are indicative of a block in fatty acid oxidation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • This question aims to assess the understanding of fatty acid oxidation disorders, specifically focusing on the role of acyl-CoA dehydrogenase in β-oxidation.
  • The correct diagnosis is based on recognizing the clinical presentation of hypoglycemia during fasting, elevated urine dicarboxylic acids, and connecting these findings to an enzymatic deficiency in the fatty acid oxidation pathway.
  • Understanding the roles of other enzymes listed as options helps distinguish between different metabolic pathways and their contributions to energy production and metabolic homeostasis.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with left oculomotor nerve palsy. Which of the following movements is spared?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intorsion

 

  • This movement is primarily controlled by the superior oblique muscle, which is innervated by the trochlear nerve (Cranial Nerve IV), not the oculomotor nerve.
  • Therefore, intorsion is spared in oculomotor nerve palsy.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Depression. The primary muscle for depression of the eye is the inferior rectus, which is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. This movement would be affected in oculomotor nerve palsy.

 

Option C. Adduction. This movement is controlled by the medial rectus muscle, which is also innervated by the oculomotor nerve. Thus, adduction is impaired in oculomotor nerve palsy.

 

Option D. Elevation. The superior rectus, which is responsible for elevation of the eye, is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. This movement would be compromised in oculomotor nerve palsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In oculomotor nerve palsy, intorsion, controlled by the superior oblique muscle and innervated by the trochlear nerve, is the movement that is spared.

choices.text: Medical dissolution therapy
ERCP and stone removal

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman was undergoing a routine check-up when the radiologist noticed gallstones on USG. However, the patient says that there have been no complaints so far and she is asymptomatic. The stone measures 4cms. What will be your treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Laparoscopic cholecystectomy

 

  • Asymptomatic gallstones do not need intervention however prophylactic cholecystectomy may be performed for asymptomatic cholelithiasis in the following situations:
    • Large (>3 cm) gallstones;
    • Choledocholithiasis;
    • Chronic haemolytic conditions (sickle cell disease, hereditary spherocytosis);
    • Gallbladder polyps >1 cm in diameter;
    • Suspicion/risk of malignancy (anomalous pancreatic ductal drainage);
    • Calcification of the wall (porcelain gallbladder);
    • Some ethnic groups or subjects living in areas with a high prevalence of gallbladder cancer associated with gallstones (some parts of northern India, Native Americans, Mexican Americans, Colombia, Chile, Bolivia);
    • Transplant patients (during transplantation);
    • Bariatric surgery.
  • While asymptomatic gallstones generally do not require treatment, prophylactic laparoscopic cholecystectomy is recommended for stones larger than 3 cm due to the increased risk of gallbladder cancer and other complications.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Conservative management is the standard treatment for asymptomatic gallstones that do not meet criteria for cholecystectomy. However, given the size of the stone in this patient, conservative management is not the best choice.

 

Option C. Medical dissolution therapy is typically reserved for patients who refuse or are not candidates for surgery due to comorbidities. The effectiveness is variable and less likely to be successful with larger stones.

 

Option D. ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) and stone removal are used for stones in the common bile duct, not for gallstones in the gallbladder itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Prophylactic cholecystectomy may be performed in asymptomatic patients with risk factors that predispose them to complications, such as having large gallstones greater than 3 cm, which is the case with this patient.
  • This approach is aimed at preventing future gallstone-related complications.

 

Ref: Bailey, 28th Edition, Page no. 1244

questions.text: A clinical trial comparing a new drug 'A' to a placebo 'B' reveals differing rates of adverse outcomes. With 15,225 patients in each group, the new drug 'A' had 1,605 adverse outcomes, whereas the placebo 'B' had 1,804. To evaluate the efficacy of drug 'A', what are the Relative Risk Reduction (RRR) and Absolute Risk Reduction (ARR)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) RRR 11%, ARR 1%

 

 

In the given question,

 

    •  
  • Event rate Drug = 1605/15225 × 100 = 10.5% (0.105)
  • Event rate Placebo = 1804/15225 × 100 = 11.8% (0.118)

 

Hence,

 

    •  
  • Relative risk of Event rate = Event rate drug/Event rate Placebo = 0.105/0.118 = 0.9
  • Relative risk reduction (RRR) = (Event rate Placebo – Event rate drug)/Event rate placebo = (0.118)– 0.105)/0.118 = 0.11 = 11%
  • Absolute risk reduction = Event rate Drug – Event rate Placebo = 0.105 – 0.118 = – 0.013 = – 1.3%

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Relative risk reduction (RRR): Percentage reduction in one outcome (E.g. Death or Adverse outcome) comparing one group (New drug) with another group (Older drug or Placebo)
  • Absolute risk reduction (ARR): Reduction in outcome (E.g. Death or Adverse outcome) comparing one group (New drug) with another group (Older drug or Placebo)

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with generalized lymphadenopathy, fatigue, weight loss, and biopsy showing small to medium lymphocytes with irregular nuclei and Cyclin D1 positivity is likely facing which condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mantle Cell Lymphoma

 

  • Mantle Cell Lymphoma (MCL) is characterized by the overexpression of Cyclin D1, which is a key regulator of the cell cycle.
  • The translocation t(11;14) (q13;q32) is commonly found in MCL, leading to the overexpression of Cyclin D1.
  • This protein promotes the progression from the G1 phase to the S phase of the cell cycle, contributing to the uncontrolled growth of the lymphoma cells.
  • The presence of Cyclin D1 positivity on immunohistochemistry is a hallmark feature of MCL and aids in its distinction from other types of lymphomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Follicular Lymphoma. This type of lymphoma is typically characterized by the translocation t(14;18) (q32;q21), leading to the overexpression of the BCL-2 protein, not Cyclin D1. It usually presents with a nodular or follicular pattern on histology.

 

Option B. Marginal Zone Lymphoma. Marginal zone lymphomas, including MALT lymphomas, are usually negative for Cyclin D1. They are associated with chronic inflammation or autoimmune diseases and have distinct morphological and immunophenotypic features.

 

Option D. Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL). CLL is characterized by the proliferation of small, mature-appearing lymphocytes in the peripheral blood, bone marrow, and lymphoid tissues. Cyclin D1 is not typically overexpressed in CLL, making it an unlikely diagnosis when Cyclin D1 positivity is observed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Mantle Cell Lymphoma is marked by Cyclin D1 positivity due to a characteristic genetic translocation helps distinguish it from other lymphoma types such as Follicular Lymphoma, Marginal Zone Lymphoma, and CLL, which have different genetic and immunophenotypic profiles.

choices.text: A physiotherapist focusing on rehabilitation
A counsellor aiding in coping strategies and family dynamics
A vocational advisor helping disabled individuals find employment
A clinician primarily treating physical ailments

questions.text: A community health centre in India is looking to expand its team to better address the psychosocial needs of its patients. Which of the following professionals would be most suited to fulfil the role of a social worker within this healthcare setting?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A counsellor aiding in coping strategies and family dynamics

 

  • The role of a social worker in a healthcare setting is primarily to address the psychosocial aspects of patient care, which includes providing support for mental health, facilitating coping strategies, and assisting with interpersonal and family dynamics.
  • This aligns with the role of a counsellor described in option B).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A physiotherapist focusing on rehabilitation. Focuses on physical rehabilitation, which does not encompass the full scope of social work.

 

Option C. A vocational advisor helping disabled individuals find employment. While important, this role is more specialized and does not cover the broader psychosocial support offered by social workers.

 

Option D. A clinician primarily treating physical ailments. Concentrates on the medical treatment of physical conditions, differing from the psychosocial support role of social workers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The importance of addressing psychosocial needs in healthcare, highlighting the role of social workers in providing comprehensive patient care through support in coping strategies, mental health, and family dynamics.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with episodic dizziness and headaches has an MRI showing brain capillary telangiectasias. Considering the common bleeding sites for these malformations, which brain site is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Brainstem

 

  • Capillary telangiectasias are small, dilated blood vessels in the brain that are often found incidentally on imaging and are usually asymptomatic.
  • When symptomatic, they can present with headaches, seizures, or focal neurological deficits depending on their location.
  • The brainstem is the most frequent site of clinically significant bleeding from capillary telangiectasias, given its critical function and the density of critical structures within a small area.
  • Bleeding in this region, although rare, can lead to significant neurological impairments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Putamen. The putamen is a common site for hypertensive hemorrhages but is not the most frequent site of bleeding associated with capillary telangiectasias.

 

Option B. Thalamus. The thalamus is another site where hypertensive and deep brain hemorrhages commonly occur but is not specifically associated with a higher risk of bleeding from capillary telangiectasias compared to the brainstem.

 

Option D. Globus pallidus. The globus pallidus is involved in movement regulation and is also a site for hypertensive hemorrhages, but it is not the most common site for bleeding from capillary telangiectasias.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The brainstem is the most common site of clinically significant bleeding from capillary telangiectasias.

questions.text: In a microbiology laboratory session focused on diagnostic techniques, medical students are presented with a case study involving a patient with a bacterial infection. As part of the diagnostic process, a Gram stain is performed on a sample obtained from the patient, revealing that the causative organism stains pink/red under the microscope. The instructor asks the students to identify the characteristic components of the cell wall of the organism based on the Gram staining result. Given that the organism appears pink/red, indicating it is Gram-negative, which component(s) are characteristic of the cell wall of this organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lipopolysaccharides

 

  • The pink/red coloration observed in the Gram stain indicates that the organism is Gram-negative.
  • A key characteristic of the cell wall of Gram-negative bacteria is the presence of lipopolysaccharides (LPS) in the outer membrane.
  • LPS is a complex molecule consisting of lipids and polysaccharides, which contributes to the structural integrity of the cell wall and can elicit a strong immune response in the host.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Peptidoglycan. While peptidoglycan is a component of the cell walls of both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria, it is not the defining characteristic of Gram-negative bacteria in the context of a Gram stain. Gram-negative bacteria have a thinner layer of peptidoglycan than Gram-positive bacteria.

 

Option C. Lipids. While lipids are present in the cell walls of Gram-negative bacteria, particularly in the outer membrane, the specific component that is characteristic and unique to Gram-negative bacteria in the context of Gram staining is lipopolysaccharides (LPS).

 

Option D. Teichoic acid. Teichoic acids are found in the cell walls of Gram-positive bacteria, not Gram-negative bacteria, and are involved in the regulation of cell wall autolysis and ion movement.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A public health officer is tasked with assessing and ensuring the safety of community well water in a rural village in India. During a routine inspection, the officer uses Horrock's apparatus to test the chlorine demand of the water. The test indicates that the third cup turns blue, signalling a specific chlorine demand to effectively disinfect the water. Considering the volume of the community well is approximately 9100 litres, the officer must calculate the precise amount of bleaching powder required to ensure the water is safe for consumption. Based on the results from Horrock's apparatus, what is the correct amount of bleaching powder needed for the disinfection of 9100 litres of water?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 120 grams

 

  • Dose of bleaching powder required (Chlorine demand): n × 2 gm to disinfect 455 litres of water (where n = no. of first cup which shows distinct blue colour in Horrock’s apparatus)
  • In the given question, 3rd cup shows blue colour so 3 × 2 grams (6 grams) will disinfect 455 litres of water.
  • Hence, 9100 litres will require 6/455 × 9100 = 120 grams bleaching powder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The application of Horrock's apparatus is in determining the chlorine demand for water disinfection and to calculate the required amount of bleaching powder based on the volume of water and the desired chlorine concentration.

choices.text: Henoch schonlein purpura (HSP)
Immune thrombocytopenia (ITP)
Dengue
Minimal change disease (MCD)

questions.text: A child presents with palpable blanching purpura predominantly on the lower limbs, abdominal pain, arthritis predominantly affecting the knee joint, and renal involvement as evidenced by hematuria and proteinuria. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Henoch schonlein purpura (HSP)

 

  • Henoch Schonlein Purpura (HSP) is a small vessel vasculitis associated with IgA deposition and is characterized by the classic tetrad of palpable purpura (often on the lower limbs), abdominal pain, renal involvement (hematuria and proteinuria), and arthritis.
  • This constellation of symptoms fits with the clinical presentation described.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Immune thrombocytopenia (ITP). ITP is a hematological disorder characterized by thrombocytopenia and purpura but is not typically associated with abdominal pain, arthritis, or renal involvement.

 

Option C. Dengue fever can cause purpura due to thrombocytopenia and may lead to joint pains, but it does not typically present with the renal involvement described here or the palpable purpura specific to HSP.
