  • C. burnetii endocarditis is notable for being a culture-negative endocarditis, as the organism is not readily cultured by standard blood culture techniques.
  • The patient's occupational exposure and the presentation of a febrile illness with endocarditis symptoms strongly suggest C. burnetii as the causative pathogen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ehrlichia chaffeensis. This bacterium causes human monocytic ehrlichiosis, transmitted by ticks. It primarily presents with fever, malaise, and leukopenia and is less commonly associated with endocarditis.

 

Option C. Bartonella henselae. While B. henselae, the agent of cat scratch disease, can cause culture-negative endocarditis, it is more commonly associated with contact with cats rather than livestock.

 

Option D. Tropheryma whipplei. This organism causes Whipple's disease, which can involve various systems including the gastrointestinal tract, heart, and central nervous system. However, it is not typically associated with acute presentations of endocarditis and lacks a direct link to farm animal exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Coxiella burnetii as the causative agent of chronic Q fever, which can present as endocarditis in individuals with a history of exposure to farm animals.
  • An understanding of the pathogen's obligate intracellular nature and potential for chronic infection is key for diagnosis and management.

choices.text: High dose monotherapy
Multiple seizure types

questions.text: During pregnancy, managing epilepsy poses unique challenges, and several factors can contribute to poor seizure control. Among the following options, which one is NOT typically considered a contributing factor to poor seizure control in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) High dose monotherapy

 

  • High dose monotherapy is generally not considered a factor contributing to poor seizure control in pregnancy.
  • In fact, monotherapy, even at higher doses, is often preferred over polytherapy to minimize fetal exposure to antiepileptic drugs while still maintaining seizure control.
  • The goal is to use the lowest effective dose of a single medication to reduce the risk of teratogenic effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyperemesis gravidarum. This condition involves severe nausea and vomiting, which can lead to dehydration and electrolyte imbalances, potentially worsening seizure control. Additionally, vomiting can impair the absorption of antiepileptic drugs, leading to subtherapeutic levels and poor seizure control.

 

Option C. Multiple seizure types. Having multiple types of seizures can complicate the management of epilepsy, making it harder to achieve good seizure control. Different seizure types may require different therapeutic approaches, increasing the complexity of management during pregnancy.

 

Option D. Sleep deprivation. Sleep deprivation is a well-known trigger for seizures. Pregnancy-related sleep disturbances can exacerbate this issue, contributing to poor seizure control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • This question aims to identify factors that can affect seizure control in pregnant women with epilepsy.
  • Understanding these factors is crucial for managing epilepsy during pregnancy effectively.
  • High dose monotherapy is actually a strategy to minimize fetal exposure to antiepileptic drugs while maintaining seizure control, whereas hyperemesis gravidarum, multiple seizure types, and sleep deprivation are recognized as potential contributors to poor seizure control during pregnancy.

choices.text: Respiratory bronchiolitis-associated interstitial lung disease (RB-ILD)

questions.text: A 54-year-old male smoker with progressive dyspnea, a non-productive cough, and HRCT showing interstitial lung disease (ILD) is evaluated for smoking-related lung diseases. Which interstitial lung disease is least likely linked to his smoking history?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Usual Interstitial Pneumonia (UIP)

 

  • Usual Interstitial Pneumonia (UIP) is a form of interstitial lung disease characterized by a pattern of lung injury that includes honeycombing, fibrosis with architectural distortion, and temporal heterogeneity.
  • UIP is most commonly associated with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) and is not specifically related to smoking.
  • While smoking can increase the risk of developing various forms of lung disease, including ILD, the characteristic UIP pattern on imaging and histopathology is not considered a direct consequence of smoking.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory bronchiolitis-associated interstitial lung disease (RB-ILD) is seen almost exclusively in smokers and is characterized by respiratory bronchiolitis with interstitial lung involvement.

 

Option B. Desquamative interstitial pneumonia (DIP) is strongly associated with smoking and is characterized by the accumulation of macrophages in the alveolar spaces, along with interstitial inflammation and fibrosis.

 

Option C. Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH), previously known as pulmonary histiocytosis X, is predominantly seen in young adult smokers and is characterized by the proliferation of Langerhans cells, creating nodules that can cavitate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Usual Interstitial Pneumonia (UIP) is most commonly associated with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) and is not specifically related to smoking.

questions.text: In the Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) scheme, aimed at providing nutritional support to vulnerable sections of the population in India, specific dietary recommendations are made for pregnant women to ensure maternal and fetal health. Among the options below, which one correctly outlines the dietary supplementation provided to pregnant women under the ICDS program?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 600 Kcal + 20 grams proteins

 

  • The ICDS scheme, recognizing the increased nutritional needs during pregnancy, recommends a dietary supplementation of 600 Kcal and 20 grams of proteins for pregnant women.
  • This is designed to support the health of both the mother and the developing fetus by ensuring adequate energy and protein intake.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Revised norms for free food supplementation under ICDS:

choices.text: Administration of intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG)
Use of insulin for hyperglycemia
Avoiding aminoglycoside exposure for more than 7 days
Use of antenatal steroids

questions.text: Which intervention is strongly recommended to reduce mortality and prevent future neurodevelopmental impairment in a preterm neonate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Use of antenatal steroids

 

  • Antenatal steroids are given to the mother when she pregnant and expecting a preterm labor.
  • It is given for baby’s lung maturity.
  • Inj. betamethasone 12 mg for 2 doses 24 hrs. apart.
  • Inj. dexamethasone 6 mg 4 doses 12 hours apart.
  • The use of antenatal steroids is recommended to accelerate fetal lung maturity and reduce the risks of respiratory distress syndrome, intraventricular hemorrhage, and necrotizing enterocolitis in preterm infants, all of which can impact mortality and neurodevelopmental outcomes.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Administration of intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG). IVIG administration is sometimes used in neonates, but it is not a standard recommendation for the reduction of mortality and neurodevelopmental impairment in preterm infants without a specific indication.

 

Option B. Use of insulin for hyperglycemia. While managing hyperglycemia is important, the routine use of insulin for this purpose in preterm neonates is not a standard recommendation to reduce mortality and neurodevelopmental impairment.

 

Option C. Avoiding aminoglycoside exposure for more than 7 days. Avoiding prolonged exposure to aminoglycosides can be important due to the risk of nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity, but it is not the primary intervention for reducing mortality and neurodevelopmental impairment in preterm neonates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The administration of antenatal steroids to mothers at risk of preterm delivery is strongly recommended to reduce mortality and prevent future neurodevelopmental impairment in preterm neonates by enhancing lung maturity.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male with poorly controlled diabetes and chronic kidney disease (CKD) shows gradually declining renal function and enlarged kidneys on ultrasound. Considering the etiologies of CKD, which condition is least likely to present with large kidneys in its advanced stages?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)

 

  • FSGS is a cause of nephrotic syndrome and CKD characterized by scarring in some of the glomeruli.
  • In the advanced stages of the disease, kidneys often become scarred and shrink over time, leading to smaller, not larger, kidney sizes on imaging studies such as ultrasound.
  • This contrasts with other conditions listed, which can present with larger kidneys even in later stages due to different pathophysiological mechanisms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diabetic nephropathy often leads to enlarged kidneys in the early and sometimes later stages due to hyperfiltration and hypertrophy of the nephrons, a common finding in patients with diabetes.

 

Option B. Amyloidosis can lead to enlarged kidneys due to amyloid deposition in the renal parenchyma, which can occur even as the renal function declines.

 

Option D. HIV-associated nephropathy (HIVAN) is typically associated with large kidneys on ultrasound due to collapsing FSGS and associated tubular hypertrophy, especially in the early and middle stages, and can persist into the later stages of the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the advanced stages of CKD, most conditions lead to reduced kidney size due to scarring and loss of nephron mass.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient consults an oncologist due to a recently discovered breast lump. After undergoing a thorough examination and necessary diagnostic tests, she is diagnosed with breast cancer. An echocardiogram reveals her ejection fraction to be at 25%. Considering the patient's cardiac condition, which of the following chemotherapeutic agents should be avoided to prevent exacerbation of her cardiac dysfunction?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epirubicin

 

  • Epirubicin is an anthracycline chemotherapeutic agent known for its potential cardiotoxic effects, especially in patients with pre-existing cardiac conditions.
  • The drug can lead to cardiomyopathy and congestive heart failure, which are particularly concerning in patients with a low ejection fraction, such as the 25% observed in this patient.
  • Therefore, Epirubicin should be avoided to prevent further cardiac damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Irinotecan. This drug is primarily associated with gastrointestinal side effects, such as diarrhea and neutropenia, but not with significant cardiotoxicity. Therefore, it would not be contraindicated based on the patient's low ejection fraction.

 

Option C. Cyclophosphamide. While cyclophosphamide can have cardiotoxic effects, particularly at high doses, its risk profile is generally considered lower than that of anthracyclines like Epirubicin. However, careful consideration and monitoring are still required in patients with compromised cardiac function.

 

Option D. Methotrexate. Methotrexate is associated with hepatotoxicity, mucositis, and myelosuppression but has minimal cardiotoxic effects. It would not be contraindicated in a patient with a low ejection fraction based on its side effect profile.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The key educational point in this question is to recognize the cardiotoxic potential of certain chemotherapeutic agents, particularly anthracyclines like Epirubicin, in patients with pre-existing cardiac conditions such as a reduced ejection fraction.
  • It is crucial to consider the cardiac risk profile of chemotherapeutic agents when treating cancer patients with underlying cardiac dysfunction to avoid exacerbating their condition.

questions.text: Which part of urethra would be injured in the pictures given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bulbar

 

  • Straddle injuries lead to rupture of bulbous urethra.
  • This can occur with a sharp blow to the perineum.
  • Diagnosis is made by retrograde urethrography.
  • Suprapubic cystostomy is performed.
  • Delayed urethroplasty (2-3 months later) is the surgical treatment of choice.
  • Presentation:
    • Blood at urethral meatus
    • Not being able to pass urine
    • Urine building up in the bladder (distension)
    • Butterfly-shaped perineal hematoma

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Straddle injuries lead to rupture of bulbous urethra.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery, 28th edition, page no. 1540-1541

choices.text: ATP-Sensitive K+ Channels

questions.text: The process of insulin release in response to elevated blood glucose levels represents a finely tuned physiological mechanism critical for maintaining metabolic equilibrium. The phenomena of Glucose-mediated insulin release involves:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ATP-Sensitive K+ Channels 

 

  • Glucose-mediated insulin release involves the closure of ATP-sensitive K+ channels in beta cells of the pancreas, leading to cell depolarization and subsequent insulin secretion.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. cAMP (Cyclic adenosine monophosphate). While cAMP plays a role in other hormonal pathways, it is not directly involved in the mechanism of glucose-mediated insulin release from pancreatic beta cells.

 

Option C. Carrier Modulators. This term is broad and not specifically related to the mechanism of insulin release in response to glucose levels; hence, it does not directly participate in this physiological process.

 

Option D. Receptor Phosphorylation. While receptor phosphorylation is a common cellular signalling mechanism, it is not directly associated with glucose-mediated insulin release from pancreatic beta cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understanding the role of ATP-sensitive K+ channels in glucose-mediated insulin release provides insight into the intricate mechanisms regulating pancreatic beta cell function, essential for maintaining glucose homeostasis in the body.
  • Mechanism of insulin secretion by the K+ channel in pancreatic β-cells:

 

 

  • Glucose enters the B cells via GLUT 2 transporters and is phosphorylated by Glucokinase then metabolized to pyruvate in the cytoplasm → in mitochondria, the formation of ATP by oxidative phosphorylation occurs.
  • The ATP inhibits ATP-sensitive K+ channels, reducing K+ efflux → depolarization and opening of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels.
  • The Ca2+ influx causes exocytosis of a readily releasable pool of insulin-containing secretory granules, producing the initial spike of insulin secretion.

 

Ref: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page no. 326

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient with a history of seizures presents to the clinic. He has been taking anticonvulsants for the last few years, and he reports experiencing visual disturbances, including a narrowing of his visual field. He is concerned about the possibility of permanent vision loss. Which of these anticonvulsants causes contraction of visual field?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vigabatrin

 

  • Vigabatrin is an anticonvulsant medication known to cause visual disturbances, including a narrowing of the visual field, which is a characteristic side effect of this drug.
  • Vigabatrin's mechanism of action involves the irreversible inhibition of gamma-aminobutyric acid transaminase (GABA-T), leading to increased levels of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) in the brain, which helps control seizures.
  • However, one of the serious adverse effects of vigabatrin is its potential to cause permanent vision loss, particularly peripheral vision loss or contraction of the visual field.
  • Patients on vigabatrin require regular ophthalmologic monitoring to assess for any changes in vision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Levetiracetam works by modulating neurotransmitter release through binding to the synaptic vesicle protein SV2A, and it is not commonly associated with visual disturbances or contraction of the visual field.

 

Option B. Phenytoin, a sodium channel blocker, can have a variety of side effects, but contraction of the visual field is not a characteristic adverse effect. Phenytoin's more common side effects include nystagmus, ataxia, and gingival hyperplasia, among others.

 

Option D. Ethosuximide, which is primarily used in the treatment of absence seizures, acts by inhibiting T-type calcium channels. It is not typically associated with visual field defects as a side effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The question aims to highlight the importance of recognizing the potential ocular side effects of anticonvulsant medications, specifically the risk of visual field contraction associated with vigabatrin use.
  • It underscores the need for regular ophthalmologic evaluations in patients taking vigabatrin to monitor for this serious adverse effect and illustrates the diverse side effect profiles of anticonvulsant drugs.

choices.text: Pedicled TRAM based on superior epigastric artery
Free TRAM based on inferior epigastric artery
DIEP based on deep inferior epigastric artery
DIEP is a myocutaneous flap

questions.text: Identify the false statement about the flaps used in breast reconstruction.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) DIEP is a myocutaneous flap

 

  • The image provided depicts a deep inferior epigastric artery perforator flap (DIEP).
  • The DIEP flap is derived from the deep inferior epigastric artery and is a muscle sparing flap.
  • A myocutaneous flap, by definition, includes muscle.
  • The DIEP flap is differentiated from the TRAM flap by the fact that it spares the rectus abdominis muscle and uses only the skin, fat, and blood vessels for breast reconstruction.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Pedicled TRAM based on superior epigastric artery. TRAM stands for Transverse Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous. The pedicled TRAM flap relies primarily on the superior epigastric artery, which remains attached (or "pedicled") to its original blood supply. The flap is tunneled under the skin to the chest and used to reconstruct the breast.

 

Option B. Free TRAM based on inferior epigastric artery. The free TRAM flap involves removing a section of the abdominal tissue (including the rectus muscle) and its associated blood vessels (inferior epigastric arteries). This flap is then transplanted to the chest and connected to the chest's blood vessels using microsurgical techniques. It utilizes both the superior and inferior epigastric arteries.

 

Option C. DIEP based on deep inferior epigastric artery. The DIEP (Deep Inferior Epigastric Perforator) flap is similar to the free TRAM flap but does not involve the removal of the rectus muscle. Instead, only the blood vessels (or "perforators") and the skin and fat are removed. It is based solely on the deep inferior epigastric artery. The DIEP flap reduces post-operative abdominal weakness and complications because it spares the abdominal muscles.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The DIEP flap is derived from the deep inferior epigastric artery and is a muscle sparing flap.

choices.text: The surgeon must use chromic catgut.
The surgeon must not include the submucosa in the sutures.
The surgeon must use the single layer, extramucosal suture technique.
The surgeon must use the single layer, seromuscular suture technique.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the hospital with symptoms of an inguinal hernia. During the operation, the surgeon observes a segment of necrotic bowel in the hernial sac. What is the appropriate course of action for resection and anastomosis of a necrotic bowel seen during surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The surgeon must use the single layer, extramucosal suture technique.

 

  • The single-layer, extramucosal suture technique of Halstead involves using a single layer of sutures to join the two ends of the bowel together, while avoiding the mucosal layer.
  • This technique is less time-consuming than the double-layer technique and reduces the risk of complications such as bleeding, stricture formation, and anastomotic leak.
  • This is one of the preferred techniques in small bowel anastomosis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. The surgeon must use chromic catgut. Chromic catgut is a type of absorbable suture that is made from the collagen found in sheep or goat intestine. Chromic catgut has a relatively short duration of tensile strength, and so it is not recommended for use in areas of high tension or stress, including intestinal anastomosis.

 

Option B. The surgeon must not include the submucosa in the sutures. The submucosa is a layer of tissue beneath the mucosal lining of the bowel. It should be included in sutures as it is the toughest layer of the bowel.

 

Option D. The surgeon must use the single layer, seromuscular suture technique. The single-layer seromuscular suture technique involves suturing the seromuscular layer of the bowel to join the two ends together. This technique is quick and easy to perform but may not be suitable for all cases as it can increase the risk of anastomotic leakage and stenosis. Therefore, it is important to assess each case individually and choose the appropriate technique based on the specific circumstances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For resection and anastomosis of a necrotic bowel seen during surgery, the surgeon must use the single layer, extramucosal suture technique.

choices.text: Increases the secretion of enkephalin
Decreases the secretion of enkephalin
No effect on the secretion of enkephalin
Negligible effect on enkephalin secretion

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a history of chronic pain syndrome is being evaluated in a pain management clinic. Her treatment regimen includes medications that modulate neurotransmitter levels to manage her pain. One of the medical students shadowing in the clinic is curious about the role of various neurotransmitters in pain modulation and their effects on pain-modulating peptides such as enkephalins. The attending physician decides to use this opportunity to test the student's understanding of the interaction between neurotransmitters and neuropeptides involved in pain modulation. What will be the effect of serotonin on the secretion of enkephalin?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increases the secretion of enkephalin

 

  • Serotonin, a neurotransmitter known for its role in mood regulation, also plays a significant role in the modulation of pain.
  • In the context of pain pathways, serotonin released in the spinal cord can increase the secretion of enkephalin, a type of endogenous opioid peptide.
  • Enkephalins bind to opioid receptors in the central nervous system, inhibiting pain signals and thereby exerting an analgesic effect.
  • The increase in enkephalin secretion by serotonin contributes to the descending pain modulation pathway, where the brain influences the perception of pain by sending inhibitory signals to the spinal cord.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Decreases the secretion of enkephalin. This option is incorrect as serotonin generally has a facilitatory effect on the secretion of enkephalins, contributing to pain inhibition rather than decreasing their secretion.

 

Option C. No effect on the secretion of enkephalin. This option is incorrect because serotonin does influence enkephalin secretion as part of the body's complex pain modulation mechanisms.

 

Option D. Negligible effect on enkephalin secretion. This option is also incorrect. While the effect of serotonin on enkephalin secretion may vary depending on the physiological context, it is generally considered significant in the modulation of pain pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The educational objective is to understand the role of neurotransmitters like serotonin in modulating pain through their effects on neuropeptides such as enkephalins.
  • Recognizing the interplay between neurotransmitters and neuropeptides is crucial for comprehending the complex mechanisms of pain modulation and for the effective management of pain in clinical practice.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man visits the clinic with a history of recurring fevers. He reports that the fever episodes have been occurring like clockwork, every 72 hours for the past several weeks. He recently returned from a trip to sub-Saharan Africa, where he spent significant time outdoors in rural areas. The patient did not take any prophylactic antimalarial medication. Given the periodicity of the fever, which Plasmodium species is most likely responsible for the patient's malaria infection, considering the classic fever patterns associated with different species?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) P. malariae

 

  • P. malariae is known for its quartan fever pattern, which occurs every 72 hours.
  • This is due to the parasite's 72-hour erythrocytic cycle.
  • The patient's reported pattern of recurring fever matches the quartan cycle associated with P. malariae infection, making it the most likely cause of his malaria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. P. falciparum. Typically causes a more irregular fever pattern, often with more severe and life-threatening symptoms.

 

Option B. P. vivax and Option C. P. ovale. Both of these species can cause tertian fever patterns, with fevers typically recurring every 48 hours.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Other differences between the species of Plasmodium:

choices.text: Fetal blood sampling
MCA (Middle cerebral artery) doppler peak systolic velocity

questions.text: In modern obstetrics, which of the following investigations is used for monitoring the fetus of an Rh-negative sensitized mother?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) MCA (Middle cerebral artery) doppler peak systolic velocity

 

  • A Doppler of the middle cerebral artery indirectly gives evidence of fetal anemia.
  • An anemic fetus (For e.g. due to fetal red cell destruction in an Rh iso-immunized mother) will re-direct blood flow to more important organs like the brain.
  • This is reflected by an increased flow in the middle cerebral artery which can be measured by doing a Doppler of the MCA.
  • In Rh immunized mothers, when indirect Coomb’s Test (ICT) titers rise above the critical titer of 1:16, then MCA doppler peak systolic velocity (PSV) is used for monitoring fetal anemia and development of hydrops in these babies.
  • MCA-PSV has replaced amniocentesis as it is a non-invasive test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biophysical Profile is a test of antepartum fetal assessment.

 

Option B. Fetal blood sampling or Cordocentesis. This is done only when the fetal MCA doppler shows a peak systolic velocity of > 1.5 MoMs.

 

Option C. Amnio-spectrometry. This is no longer done as it is an invasive method of measuring the amount of bilirubin in the amniotic fluid to determine the level of fetal anemia.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

  • A Doppler of the middle cerebral artery indirectly gives evidence of fetal anemia.
  • An anemic fetus (For e.g. due to fetal red cell destruction in an Rh iso-immunized mother) will re-direct blood flow to more important organs like the brain.
  • This is reflected by an increased flow in the middle cerebral artery which can be measured by doing a Doppler of the MCA.
  • In Rh immunized mothers, when indirect Coomb’s Test (ICT) titers rise above the critical titer of 1:16, then MCA doppler peak systolic velocity (PSV) is used for monitoring fetal anemia and development of hydrops in these babies.
  • MCA-PSV has replaced amniocentesis as it is a non-invasive test.

 

Ref: William’s Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no. 931

questions.text: A 54-year-old man is being treated for a pulmonary abscess. He has received broad spectrum antibiotic therapy with nafcillin, cephalosporins, and gentamicin for the past 14 days. He has developed abdominal pain, fever, and diarrhea over the past 3 days. The gross appearance of his colonic mucosa is shown here. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pseudomembranous colitis

 

  • The clinical history of broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy, especially including cepahlosporins, followed by abdominal pain, fever, and diarrhea, is highly suggestive of pseudomembranous colitis.
  • The colonic mucosa's gross appearance, characterized by yellowish plaques or pseudomembrane, is pathognomonic for pseudomembranous colitis, which results from overgrowth of Clostridium difficile.
  • This bacterium releases toxins that cause mucosal inflammation, leading to the formation of pseudomembrane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amoebiasis could present with diarrhea and abdominal pain but typically has a different endoscopic appearance, often with flask-shaped ulcers rather than pseudomembrane, and would not be expected after broad-spectrum antibiotic use.

 

Option B. Angiodysplasia is a vascular abnormality that can cause bleeding in the gastrointestinal tract, typically presenting with painless bleeding rather than diarrhea and is not associated with recent antibiotic use.

 

Option C. Crohn's disease is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease that can cause abdominal pain, diarrhea, and fever. However, the endoscopic appearance often shows deep longitudinal ulcers and a cobblestone pattern, which are not seen in this image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • This question tests the ability to recognize pseudomembranous colitis's clinical presentation and characteristic endoscopic findings.
  • It's crucial to identify this condition given its association with recent antibiotic use and the potential for severe complications.
  • Understanding the differences in presentation and endoscopic findings among various colitides is important for accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment.
